dedbody.line: The loue I dedicate to your
Moity. The warrant I haue of
not the worth of my vntutord
Lines makes it aſſured of acceptance. VVhat I haue
done is yours, what I haue to dœ is yours, being
part in all I haue, deuoted yours. VVere my worth
greater, my duety would ſhew greater, meane time,
as it is, it is bound to your Lordſhip; To whom I wiſh
long life ſtill lengthned with all happineſſe.

argument.subtitle: The Argvment.
argument.line: LVcius Tarquinius (for his exceſſiue pride ſurnamed Supērbus)
aﬅer hee had cauſed his owne father in law Seruius Tullius to

line.italic: be cruelly murdred, and contrarie to the Romaine Lawes and cu-
ſtomes, not requiring or ſtaying for the peoples ſuffrages, had poſſeſſed
himſelfe of the kingdome: went accompanyed with his ſonnes and other

argument.line: Noble men of Rome, to beſiege Ardea, during which ſiege, the principall
men of the Army meeting one euening at the Tent of Sextus Tarquini-
us the Kings ſonne, in their diſcourſes aﬅer ſupper euery one commended
the vertues of his owne wife: among whom Colatinus extolled the incom-
parable chaﬆity of his wife Lucretia. In that pleaſant humor they all po-

line.italic: ſted to Rome, and intending by theyr ſecret and ſodaine arriuall to make

argument.line: triall of that which euery one had before auouched, onely Colatinus ﬁnds

line.italic: his wife (though it were late in the night) ſpinning amongeſt her maides,
the other Ladies were all found dauncing and reuelling, or in ſeuerall diſ-

argument.line: ports; whereupon the Noble men yeelded Colatinus the viƈtory, and
his wife the Fame. At that time Sextus Tarquinius being enﬂamed
with Lucrece beauty, yet ſmoothering his paſſions for the preſent, departed

line.italic: with the reſt backe to the Campe: from whence he ſhortly aﬅer priuily
withdrew himſelfe, and was (according to his eſtate) royally entertayned

argument.line: and lodged by Lucrece at Colatium. The ſame night he tretcherouſlie

line.italic: ſtealeth into her Chamber, violently rauiſht her, and early in the mor-

argument.line: ning ſpeedeth away. Lucrece in this lamentable plight, haﬆily diſpatch-

line.italic: eth Meſſengers, one to Rome for her father, another to the Campe for

argument.line: Colatine . They came, the one accompanyed with Iunius Brutus, the o-
ther with Publius Valerius: and ﬁnding Lucrece attired in mourning

line.italic: habite, demanded the cauſe of her ſorrow. Shee ﬁrſt taking an oath of
them for her reuenge: reuealed the Aƈtor, and whole maner of his dea-
ling, and withall ſodainely ſtabbed her ſelfe. Which done, with one con-

argument.line: ſent they all vowed to roote out the whole hated family of the Tarquins:
and bearing the dead body to Rome, Brutus acquainted the people with

line.italic: the dœr and manner of the vile deede: with a bitter inueƈtiue againſt the
tyranny of the King, wherewith the people were ſo moued, that with one

argument.line: conſent and a general acclamation, the Tarquins were all exiled, and the

line.italic: ſtate gouernment changed from Kings to Conſuls.

stanza.line: From the beſieged Ardea all in poſt,
Borne by the truſtleſſe wings of falſe deſire,
Luſt-breathed Tarqvin, leaues the Roman hoſt,
And to Colatium beares the lightleſſe ﬁre,
VVhich in pale embers hid, lurkes to aſpire,
stanza.couplet: And girdle with embracing ﬂames, the waſt
Of Colatines fair loue, Lvcrece the chaſt.

stanza.line: Hap’ly that name of chaſt, vnhap’ly ſet
This bateleſſe edge on his keene appetite:
VVhen Colatine vnwiſely did not let,
To praiſe the cleare vnmatched red and white,
VVhich triumpht in that skie of his delight:
stanza.couplet: VVhere mortal ſtars as bright as heauēs Beauties,
VVith pure aſpeƈts did him peculiar dueties.

stanza.line: For he the night before in Tarquins Tent,
Vnlockt the treaſure of his happie ſtate:
VVhat priſeleſſe wealth the heauens had him lent,
In the poſſeſſion of his beauteous mate.
Reckning his fortune at ſuch high proud rate,
stanza.couplet: That Kings might be eſpowſed to more fame,
But King nor Peere to ſuch a peereleſſe dame.

stanza.line: O happineſſe enioy’d but of a few,
And if poſſeſt as ſoone decayed and done:
As is the morning ſiluer melting dew,
Againſt the golden ſplendour of the Sunne.
An expir’d date canceld ere well begunne.
stanza.couplet: Honour and Beautie in the owners armes,
Are weakelie fortreſt from a world of harmes.

stanza.line: Beautie it ſelfe doth of it ſelfe perſwade,
The eies of men without an Orator,
What needeth then Appologie be made
To ſet forth that which is ſo ſinguler?
Or why is Colatine the publiſher
stanza.couplet: Of that rich iewell he ſhould keepe vnknown,
From theeuiſh eares becauſe it is his owne?

stanza.line: Perchance his boſt of Lucrece Sou’raigntie,
Suggeſted this proud iſſue of a King:
For by our eares our hearts oﬅ taynted be:
Perchance that enuie of ſo rich a thing
Brauing compare, diſdainefully did ſting
stanza.couplet: His high picht thoughts that meaner men ſhould vant,
That golden hap which their ſuperiors want.

stanza.line: But ſome vntimelie thought did inſtigate,
His all too timeleſſe ſpeede if none of thoſe,
His honor, his affaires, his friends, his ſtate,
Negleƈted all, with ſwiﬅ intent he gœs,
To quench the coale which in his liuer glowes.
stanza.couplet: O raſh falſe heate, wrapt in repentant cold,
Thy haſtie ſpring ſtill blaſts and nere growes old.

stanza.line: VVhen at Colatium this falſe Lord ariued,
VVell was he welcom’d by the Romaine dame,
VVithin whoſe face Beautie and Vertue ſtriued,
VVhich of them both ſhould vnderprop her fame.
VVhē Vertue brag’d, Beautie wold bluſh for ſhame,
stanza.couplet: VVhen Beautie boſted bluſhes, in deſpight
Vertue would ſtaine that ore with ſiluer white.

stanza.line: But Beautie in that white entituled,
From Venus doues doth challenge that faire ﬁeld,
Then Vertue claimes from Beautie, Beauties red,
VVhich Vertue gaue the golden age, to guild
Their ſiluer cheekes, and cald it then their ſhield,
stanza.couplet: Teaching them thus to vſe it in the ﬁght,
VVhē ſhame aſſaild, the red ſhould fēce the white.

stanza.line: This Herauldry in Lvcrece face was ſeene,
Argued by Beauties red and Vertues white,
Of eithers colour was the other Queene:
Prouing from worlds minority their right,
Yet their ambition makes them ſtill to ﬁght:
stanza.couplet: The ſoueraignty of either being ſo great,
That oﬅ they interchange ech others ſeat.

stanza.line: This ſilent warre of Lillies and of Roſes,
VVhich Tarqvin vew’d in her faire faces ﬁeld,
In their pure rankes his traytor eye encloſes,
VVhere leaſt betweene them both it ſhould be kild.
The coward captiue vanquiſhed, doth yeeld
stanza.couplet: To thoſe two Armies that would let him gœ,
Rather then triumph in ſo falſe a fœ.

stanza.line: Now thinkes he that her husbands ſhallow tongue,
The niggard prodigall that praiſde her ſo:
In that high taske hath done her Beauty wrong.
VVhich farre exceedes his barren skill to ſhow.
Therefore that praiſe which Colatine doth owe,
stanza.couplet: Inchaunted Tarqvin aunſwers with ſurmiſe,
In ſilent wonder of ſtill gazing eyes.

stanza.line: This earthly ſainƈt adored by this deuill,
Little ſuſpeƈteth the falſe worſhipper:
“For vnſtaind thoughts do ſeldom dream on euill.
“Birds neuer lim’d, no ſecret buſhes feare:
So guiltleſſe ſhee ſecurely giues good cheare,
stanza.couplet: And reuerend welcome to her princely gueſt,
VVhoſe inward ill no outward harme expreſt.

stanza.line: For that he colourd with his high eſtate,
Hiding baſe ſin in pleats of Maieſtie:
That nothing in him ſeemd inordinate,
Saue ſometime too much wonder of his eye,
VVhich hauing all, all could not ſatisﬁe;
stanza.couplet: But poorly rich ſo wanteth in his ſtore,
That cloy’d with much, he pineth ſtill for more.

stanza.line: But ſhe that neuer cop’t with ſtraunger eies,
Could picke no meaning from their parling lookes,
Nor read the ſubtle ſhining ſecrecies,
VVrit in the glaſſie margents of ſuch bookes,
Shee toucht no vnknown baits, nor feard no hooks,
stanza.couplet: Nor could ſhee moralize his wanton ſight,
More then his eies were opend to the light.

stanza.line: He ſtories to her eares her husbands fame,
VVonne in the ﬁelds of fruitfull Italie:
And decks with praiſes Colatine s high name,
Made glorious by his manlie chiualrie,
VVith bruiſed armes and wreathes of viƈtorie,
stanza.couplet: Her ioie with heaued-vp hand ſhe doth expreſſe,
And wordleſſe ſo greetes heauen for his ſucceſſe.

stanza.line: Far from the purpoſe of his comming thither,
He makes excuſes for his being there,
No clowdie ſhow of ſtormie bluſtring wether,
Doth yet in his faire welkin once appeare,
Till ſable Night mother of dread and feare,
stanza.couplet: Vppon the world dim darkneſſe doth diſplaie,
And in her vaultie priſon, ſtowes the daie.

stanza.line: For then is Tarquine brought vnto his bed,
Intending wearineſſe with heauie ſprite:
For aﬅer ſupper long he queſtioned,
VVith modeſt Lucrece, and wore out the night,
Now leaden ſlumber with liues ſtrength doth ﬁght,
stanza.couplet: And euerie one to reſt himſelfe betakes,
Saue theeues, and cares, and troubled minds that wakes.

stanza.line: As one of which doth Tarquin lie reuoluing
The ſundrie dangers of his wils obtaining:
Yet euer to obtain his will reſoluing,
Though weake built hopes perſwade him to abſtaining
Deſpaire to gaine doth trafﬁque oﬅ for gaining,
stanza.couplet: And when great treaſure is the meede propoſed,
Though death be adiūƈt, ther’s no death ſuppoſed.

stanza.line: Thoſe that much couet are with gaine ſo fond,
That what they haue not, that which they poſſeſſe
They ſcatter and vnlooſe it from their bond,
And ſo by hoping more they haue but leſſe,
Or gaining more, the proﬁte of exceſſe
stanza.couplet: Is but to ſurfet, and ſuch griefes ſuſtaine,
That they proue bāckrout in this poore rich gain.

stanza.line: The ayme of all is but to nourſe the life,
VVith honor, wealth, and eaſe in wainyng age:
And in this ayme there is ſuch thwarting ſtrife,
That one for all, or all for one, we gage:
As life for honour, in fell battailes rage,
stanza.couplet: Honor for wealth, and oﬅ that wealth doth coſt
The death of all, and altogether loſt.

stanza.line: So that in ventring ill, we leaue to be
The things we are, for that which we expeƈt:
And this ambitious foule inﬁrmitie,
In hauing much torments vs with defeƈt
Of that we haue: ſo then we dœ negleƈt
stanza.couplet: The thing we haue, and all for want of wit,
Make ſomething nothing, by augmenting it.

stanza.line: Such hazard now muſt doting Tarqvin make,
Pawning his honor to obtaine his luſt,
And for himſelfe, himſelfe he muſt forſake.
Then where is truth if there be no ſelfe-truſt?
VVhen ſhall he thinke to ﬁnd a ſtranger iuſt,
stanza.couplet: VVhen he himſelfe, himſelfe confounds, betraies,
To ſclandrous tongues & wretched hateful daies?

stanza.line: Now ſtole vppon the time the dead of night,
VVhen heauie ſleep had cloſd vp mortall eyes,
No comfortable ſtarre did lend his light,
No noiſe but Owles, & wolues death-boding cries:
Now ſerues the ſeaſon that they may ſurpriſe
stanza.couplet: The ſillie Lambes, pure thoughts are dead & ſtill,
VVhile Luſt and Murder wakes to ſtaine and kill.

stanza.line: And now this luſtfull Lord leapt from his bed,
Throwing his mantle rudely ore his arme,
Is madly toſt betweene deſire and dred;
Th’one ſweetly ﬂatters, th’other feareth harme,
But honeſt feare, bewicht with luſtes foule charme,
stanza.couplet: Doth too too oﬅ betake him to retire,
Beaten away by braineſicke rude deſire.

stanza.line: His Faulchon on a ﬂint he ſoﬅly ſmiteth,
That from the could ſtone ſparkes of ﬁre dœ ﬂie,
VVhereat a waxen torch forthwith he lighteth,
VVhich muſt be lodeſtarre to his luſtfull eye.
And to the ﬂame thus ſpeakes aduiſedlie;
stanza.couplet: As from this cold ﬂint I enforſt this ﬁre,
So Lvcrece muſt I force to my deſire.

stanza.line: Here pale with feare he doth premeditate,
The daungers of his lothſome enterpriſe:
And in his inward mind he doth debate,
VVhat following ſorrow may on this ariſe.
Then looking ſcornfully, he doth deſpiſe
stanza.couplet: His naked armour of ſtill ſlaughtered luſt,
And iuſtly thus controlls his thoughts vniuſt.

stanza.line: Faire torch burne out thy light, and lend it not
To darken her whoſe light excelleth thine:
And die vnhallowed thoughts, before you blot
VVith your vncleanneſſe, that which is diuine:
Offer pure incenſe to ſo pure a ſhrine:
stanza.couplet: Let faire humanitie abhor the deede,
That ſpots & ſtains loues modeſt ſnow-white weed.

stanza.line: O ſhame to knighthood, and to ſhining Armes,
O foule diſhonor to my houſhoulds graue:
O impious aƈt including all foule harmes.
A martiall man to be ſoﬅ fancies ſlaue,
True valour ſtill a true reſpeƈt ſhould haue,
stanza.couplet: Then my digreſſion is ſo vile, ſo baſe,
That it will liue engrauen in my face.

stanza.line: Yea though I die the ſcandale will ſuruiue,
And be an eie-ſore in my golden coate:
Some lothſome daſh the Herrald will contriue,
To cipher me how fondlie I did dote:
That my poſteritie ſham’d with the note
stanza.couplet: Shall curſe my bones, and hold it for no ſinne,
To wiſh that I their father had not beene.

stanza.line: VVhat win I if I gaine the thing I ſeeke?
A dreame, a breath, a froth of ﬂeeting ioy,
VVho buies a minutes mirth to waile a weeke?
Or ſels eternitie to get a toy?
For one ſweete grape who will the vine deſtroy?
stanza.couplet: Or what fond begger, but to touch the crowne,
VVould with the ſcepter ſtraight be ſtrokē down?

stanza.line: If Colatinvs dreame of my intent,
VVill he not wake, and in a deſp’rate rage
Poſt hither, this vile purpoſe to preuent?
This ſiege that hath ingirt his marriage,
This blur to youth, this ſorrow to the ſage,
stanza.couplet: This dying vertue, this ſuruiuing ſhame,
VVhoſe crime will beare an euer-during blame.

stanza.line: O what excuſe can my inuention make
VVhen thou ſhalt charge me with ſo blacke a deed?
VVill not my tongue be mute, my fraile ioints ſhake?
Mine eies forgo their light, my falſe hart bleede?
The guilt beeing great, the feare doth ſtill exceede;
stanza.couplet: And extreme feare can neither ﬁght nor ﬂie,
But cowardlike with trembling terror die.

stanza.line: Had Colatinvs kild my ſonne or ſire,
Or laine in ambuſh to betray my life,
Or were he not my deare friend, this deſire
Might haue excuſe to worke vppon his wife:
As in reuenge or quittall of ſuch ſtrife.
stanza.couplet: But as he is my kinſman, my deare friend,
The ſhame and fault ﬁnds no excuſe nor end.

stanza.line: Shamefull it is: I, if the faƈt be knowne,
Hatefull it is: there is no hate in louing,
Ile beg her loue: but ſhe is not her owne:
The worſt is but deniall and reproouing.
My will is ſtrong paſt reaſons weake remoouing:
stanza.couplet: VVho feares a ſentence or an old mans ſaw,
Shall by a painted cloth be kept in awe.

stanza.line: Thus graceleſſe holds he diſputation,
Tweene frozen conſcience and hot burning will,
And with good thoughts makes diſpenſation,
Vrging the worſer ſence for vantage ſtill.
VVhich in a moment doth confound and kill
stanza.couplet: All pure effeƈts, and doth ſo farre proceede,
That what is vile, ſhewes like a vertuous deede.

stanza.line: Quoth he, ſhe tooke me kindlie by the hand,
And gaz’d for tidings in my eager eyes,
Fearing ſome hard newes from the warlike band,
VVhere her beloued Colatinvs lies.
O how her feare did make her colour riſe!
stanza.couplet: Firſt red as Roſes that on Lawne we laie,
Then white as Lawne the Roſes tooke awaie.

stanza.line: And how her hand in my hand being lockt,
Forſt it to tremble with her loyall feare:
VVhich ſtrooke her ſad, and then it faſter rockt,
Vntill her husbands welfare ſhee did heare.
VVhereat ſhee ſmiled with ſo ſweete a cheare,
stanza.couplet: That had Narcissvs ſeene her as ſhee ſtood,
Selfe-loue had neuer drown’d him in the ﬂood.

stanza.line: VVhy hunt I then for colour or excuſes?
All Orators are dumbe when Beautie pleadeth,
Poore wretches haue remorſe in poore abuſes,
Loue thriues not in the hart that ſhadows dreadeth,
Affeƈtion is my Captaine and he leadeth.
stanza.couplet: And when his gaudie banner is diſplaide,
The coward ﬁghts, and will not be diſmaide.

stanza.line: Then childiſh feare auaunt, debating die,
Reſpeƈt and reaſon waite on wrinckled age,
My heart ſhall neuer countermand mine eie.
Sad pauſe, and deepe regard beſeemes the ſage,
My part is youth and beates theſe from the ſtage.
stanza.couplet: Deſire my Pilot is, Beautie my priſe,
Then who feares ſinking where ſuch treaſure lies?

stanza.line: As corne ore-growne by weedes: ſo heedfull feare
Is almoſt choakt by vnreſiſted luſt:
Away he ſteales with open liſtning eare,
Full of foule hope, and full of fond miſtruſt:
Both which as ſeruitors to the vniuſt,
stanza.couplet: So croſſe him with their oppoſit perſwaſion,
That now he vowes a league, and now inuaſion.

stanza.line: VVithin his thought her heauenly image ſits,
And in the ſelfe ſame ſeat ſits Colatine ,
That eye which lookes on her confounds his wits,
That eye which him beholdes, as more diuine,
Vnto a view ſo falſe will not incline;
stanza.couplet: But with a pure appeale ſeekes to the heart,
VVhich once corrupted takes the worſer part.

stanza.line: And therein heartens vp his ſeruile powers,
VVho ﬂattred by their leaders iocound ſhow,
Stuffe vp his luſt: as minutes ﬁll vp howres.
And as their Captaine: ſo their pride doth grow,
Paying more ſlauiſh tribute then they owe.
stanza.couplet: By reprobate deſire thus madly led,
The Romane Lord marcheth to Lvcrece bed.

stanza.line: The lockes betweene her chamber and his will,
Ech one by him inforſt retires his ward:
But as they open they all rate his ill,
VVhich driues the creeping theefe to ſome regard,
The threſhold grates the doore to haue him heard,
stanza.couplet: Night-wandring weezels ſhreek to ſee him there,
They fright him, yet he ſtill purſues his feare.

stanza.line: As each vnwilling portall yeelds him way,
Through little vents and cranies of the place,
The wind warres with his torch, to make him ſtaie,
And blowes the ſmoake of it into his face,
Extinguiſhing his conduƈt in this caſe.
stanza.couplet: But his hot heart, which fond deſire doth ſcorch,
Puffes forth another wind that ﬁres the torch.

stanza.line: And being lighted, by the light he ſpies
Lvcrecias gloue, wherein her needle ſticks,
He takes it from the ruſhes where it lies,
And griping it, the needle his ﬁnger pricks.
As who ſhould ſay, this gloue to wanton trickes
stanza.couplet: Is not inur’d; returne againe in haſt,
Thou ſeeſt our miſtreſſe ornaments are chaſt.

stanza.line: But all theſe poore forbiddings could not ſtay him,
He in the worſt ſence conſters their deniall:
The dores, the wind, the gloue that did delay him,
He takes for accidentall things of triall.
Or as thoſe bars which ſtop the hourely diall,
stanza.couplet: VVho with a lingring ſtaie his courſe doth let,
Till euerie minute payes the howre his debt.

stanza.line: So ſo, quoth he, theſe lets attend the time,
Like little froſts that ſometime threat the ſpring,
To ad a more reioyſing to the prime,
And giue the ſneaped birds more cauſe to ſing.
Pain payes the income of ech precious thing,
stanza.couplet: Huge rocks, high winds, ſtrong pirats, ſhelues and ſands
The marchant feares, ere rich at home he lands.

stanza.line: Now is he come vnto the chamber dore,
That ſhuts him from the Heauen of his thought,
VVhich with a yeelding latch, and with no more,
Hath bard him from the bleſſed thing he ſought.
So from himſelfe impiety hath wrought,
stanza.couplet: That for his pray to pray he doth begin,
As if the Heauens ſhould countenance his ſin.

stanza.line: But in the midſt of his vnfruitfull prayer,
Hauing ſolicited th’eternall power,
That his foule thoughts might cōpaſſe his fair faire,
And they would ſtand auſpicious to the howre.
Euen there he ſtarts, quoth he, I muſt deﬂowre;
stanza.couplet: The powers to whom I pray abhor this faƈt,
How can they then aſſiſt me in the aƈt?

stanza.line: Then Loue and Fortune be my Gods, my guide,
My will is backt with reſolution:
Thoughts are but dreames till their effeƈts be tried,
The blackeſt ſinne is clear’d with abſolution.
Againſt loues ﬁre, feares froſt hath diſſolution.
stanza.couplet: The eye of Heauen is out, and miſtie night
Couers the ſhame that followes ſweet delight.

stanza.line: This ſaid, his guiltie hand pluckt vp the latch,
And with his knee the dore he opens wide,
The doue ſleeps faſt that this night Owle will catch.
Thus treaſon workes ere traitors be eſpied.
VVho ſees the lurking ſerpent ſteppes aſide;
stanza.couplet: But ſhee ſound ſleeping, fearing no ſuch thing,
Lies at the mercie of his mortall ſting.

stanza.line: Into the chamber wickedlie he ſtalkes,
And gazeth on her yet vnſtained bed:
The curtaines being cloſe, about he walkes,
Rowling his greedie eye-bals in his head.
By their high treaſon is his heart miſ led,
stanza.couplet: VVhich giues the watch word to his hand ful ſoon,
To draw the clowd that hides the ſiluer Moon.

stanza.line: Looke as the faire and fierie pointed Sunne,
Ruſhing from forth a cloud, bereaues our ſight:
Euen ſo the Curtaine drawne, his eyes begun
To winke, being blinded with a greater light.
VVhether it is that ſhee reﬂeƈts ſo bright,
stanza.couplet: That dazleth them, or elſe ſome ſhame ſuppoſed,
But blind they are, and keep themſelues incloſed.

stanza.line: O had they in that darkeſome priſon died,
Then had they ſeene the period of their ill:
Then Colatine againe by Lvcrece ſide,
In his cleare bed might haue repoſed ſtill.
But they muſt ope this bleſſed league to kill,
stanza.couplet: And holie-thoughted Lvcrece to their ſight,
Muſt ſell her ioy, her life, her worlds delight.

stanza.line: Her lillie hand, her roſie cheeke lies vnder,
Cooſning the pillow of a lawfull kiſſe;
VVho therefore angrie ſeemes to part in ſunder,
Swelling on either ſide to want his bliſſe.
Betweene whoſe hils her head intombed is;
stanza.couplet: VVhere like a vertuous Monument ſhee lies,
To be admir’d of lewd vnhallowed eyes.

stanza.line: VVithout the bed her other faire hand was,
On the greene couerlet whoſe perfeƈt white
Showed like an Aprill dazie on the graſſe,
VVith pearlie ſwet reſembling dew of night.
Her eyes like Marigolds had ſheath’d their light,
stanza.couplet: And canopied in darkeneſſe ſweetly lay,
Till they might open to adorne the day.

stanza.line: Her haire like goldē threeds playd with her breath,
O modeſt wantons, wanton modeſtie!—
Showing lifes triumph in the map of death,
And deaths dim looke in lifes mortalitie.
Ech in her ſleepe themſelues ſo beautiﬁe,
stanza.couplet: As if betweene them twaine there were no ſtrife,
But that life liu’d in death, and death in life.

stanza.line: Her breaſts like Iuory globes circled with blew,
A paire of maiden worlds vnconquered,
Saue of their Lord, no bearing yoke they knew,
And him by oath they truely honored.
Theſe worlds in Tarqvin new ambition bred,
stanza.couplet: VVho like a fowle vſurper went about,
From this faire throne to heaue the owner out.

stanza.line: VVhat could he ſee but mightily he noted?
VVhat did he note, but ſtrongly he deſired?
VVhat he beheld, on that he ﬁrmely doted,
And in his will his wilfull eye he tyred.
VVith more then admiration he admired
stanza.couplet: Her azure vaines, her alablaſter skinne,
Her corall lips, her ſnow-white dimpled chin.

stanza.line: As the grim Lion fawneth ore his pray,
Sharpe hunger by the conqueſt ſatisﬁed:
So ore this ſleeping ſoule doth Tarqvin ſtay,
His rage of luſt by gazing qualiﬁed;
Slakt, not ſuppreſt, for ſtanding by her ſide,
stanza.couplet: His eye which late this mutiny reſtraines,
Vnto a greater vprore tempts his vaines.

stanza.line: And they like ſtragling ſlaues for pillage ﬁghting,
Obdurate vaſſals fell exploits effeƈting,
In bloody death and rauiſhment delighting;
Nor childrens tears nor mothers grones reſpeƈting,
Swell in their pride, the onſet ſtill expeƈting:
stanza.couplet: Anon his beating heart allarum ſtriking,
Giues the hot charge, & bids thē do their liking.

stanza.line: His drumming heart cheares vp his burning eye,
His eye commends the leading to his hand;
His hand as proud of ſuch a dignitie,
Smoaking with pride, marcht on, to make his ſtand
On her bare breſt, the heart of all her land;
stanza.couplet: VVhoſe ranks of blew vains as his hand did ſcale.
Leﬅ their round turrets deſtitute and pale.

stanza.line: They muſtring to the quiet Cabinet,
VVhere their deare gouerneſſe and ladie lies,
Do tell her ſhee is dreadfullie beſet,
And fright her with confuſion of their cries.
Shee much amaz’d breakes ope her lockt vp eyes,
stanza.couplet: VVho peeping foorth this tumult to behold,
Are by his ﬂaming torch dim’d and controld.

stanza.line: Imagine her as one in dead of night,
From forth dull ſleepe by dreadfull fancie waking,
That thinkes ſhee hath beheld ſome gaſtlie ſprite,
VVhoſe grim aſpeƈt ſets euerie ioint a ſhaking,
VVhat terror tis: but ſhee in worſer taking,
stanza.couplet: From ſleepe diſturbed, heedfullie doth view
The ſight which makes ſuppoſed terror trew.

stanza.line: VVrapt and confounded in a thouſand feares,
Like to a new kild bird ſhee trembling lies:
Shee dares not looke, yet winking there appeares
Quicke-ſhiﬅing Antiques vglie in her eyes.
“Such ſhadowes are the weake brains forgeries,
stanza.couplet: VVho angrie that the eyes ﬂie from their lights,
In darknes daunts thē with more dreadfull ſights.

stanza.line: His hand that yet remaines vppon her breſt,
(Rude Ram to batter ſuch an Iuorie wall:)
May feele her heart (poore Cittizen) diſtreſt,
VVounding it ſelfe to death, riſe vp and fall;
Beating her bulke, that his hand ſhakes withall.
stanza.couplet: This moues in him more rage and leſſer pittie,
To make the breach and enter this ſweet Citty.

stanza.line: Firſt like a Trompet doth his tongue begin,
To ſound a parlie to his heartleſſe fœ,
VVho ore the white ſheet peers her whiter chin,
The reaſon of this raſh allarme to know,
VVhich he by dum demeanor ſeekes to ſhow.
stanza.couplet: But ſhee with vehement prayers vrgeth ſtill,
Vnder what colour he commits this ill.

stanza.line: Thus he replies, the colour in thy face,
That euen for anger makes the Lilly pale,
And the red roſe bluſh at her owne diſgrace,
Shall plead for me and tell my louing tale.
Vnder that colour am I come to ſcale
stanza.couplet: Thy neuer conquered Fort, the fault is thine,
For thoſe thine eyes betray thee vnto mine.

stanza.line: Thus I foreſtall thee, if thou meane to chide,
Thy beauty hath enſnar’d thee to this night,
VVhere thou with patience muſt my will abide,
My will that markes thee for my earths delight,
VVhich I to conquer ſought with all my might.
stanza.couplet: But as reproofe and reaſon beat it dead,
By thy bright beautie was it newlie bred.

stanza.line: I ſee what croſſes my attempt will bring,
I know what thornes the growing roſe defends,
I thinke the honie guarded with a ſting,
All this before-hand counſell comprehends.
But VVill is deafe and hears no heedfull friends,
stanza.couplet: Onely he hath an eye to gaze on Beautie,
And dotes on what he looks, gainſt law or duety.

stanza.line: I haue debated euen in my ſoule,
VVhat wrong, what ſhame, what ſorrow I ſhal breed,
But nothing can affeƈtions courſe controull,
Or ſtop the headlong furie of his ſpeed.
I know repentant teares inſewe the deed,
stanza.couplet: Reproch, diſdaine, and deadly enmity,
Yet ſtriue I to embrace mine infamy.

stanza.line: This ſaid, hee ſhakes aloﬅ his Romaine blade,
VVhich like a Faulcon towring in the skies,
Cowcheth the fowle below with his wings ſhade,
VVhoſe crooked beake threats, if he mount he dies.
So vnder his inſulting Fauchion lies
stanza.couplet: Harmeleſſe Lvcretia marking what he tels,
VVith trembling feare: as fowl hear Faulcōs bels.

stanza.line: Lvcrece, quoth he, this night I muſt enioy thee,
If thou deny, then force muſt worke my way:
For in thy bed I purpoſe to deſtroie thee.
That done, ſome worthleſſe ſlaue of thine ile ſlay.
To kill thine Honour with thy liues decaie.
stanza.couplet: And in thy dead armes do I meane to place him,
Swearing I ſlue him ſeeing thee imbrace him.

stanza.line: So thy ſuruiuing husband ſhall remaine
The ſcornefull marke of euerie open eye,
Thy kinſmen hang their heads at this diſdaine,
Thy iſſue blur’d with nameleſſe baſtardie;
And thou the author of their obloquie,
stanza.couplet: Shalt haue thy treſpaſſe cited vp in rimes,
And ſung by children in ſucceeding times.

stanza.line: But if thou yeeld, I reſt thy ſecret friend,
The fault vnknowne is as a thought vnaƈted,
“A little harme done to a great good end,
For lawfull pollicie remaines enaƈted.
“The poyſonous ſimple ſometime is compaƈted
stanza.couplet: In a pure compound; being ſo applied,
His venome in effeƈt is puriﬁed.

stanza.line: Then for thy husband and thy childrens ſake,
Tender my ſuite, bequeath not to their lot
The ſhame that from them no deuiſe can take,
The blemiſh that will neuer be forgot:
VVorſe than a ſlauiſh wipe, or birth howrs blot,
stanza.couplet: For markes deſcried in mens natiuitie,
Are natures faultes, not their owne infamie.

stanza.line: Here with a Cockeatrice dead killing eye,
He rowſeth vp himſelfe, and makes a pauſe,
VVhile ſhee the piƈture of pure pietie,
Like a white Hinde vnder the grypes ſharpe clawes,
Pleades in a wilderneſſe where are no lawes,
stanza.couplet: To the rough beaſt, that knowes no gentle right,
Nor ought obayes but his fowle appetite.

stanza.line: But when a black-fac’d clowd the world doth thret,
In his dim miſt th’aſpiring mountaines hiding:
From earths dark-womb, ſome gentle guſt doth get,
VVhich blow theſe pitchie vapours frō their biding:
Hindring their preſent fall by this diuiding.
stanza.couplet: So his vnhallowed haſt her words delayes,
And moodie Plvto winks while Orpheus playes.

stanza.line: Yet fowle night-waking Cat he doth but dallie,
VVhile in his hold-faſt foot the weak mouſe pāteth,
Her ſad behauiour feedes his vulture follie,
A ſwallowing gulfe that euen in plentie wanteth.
His eare her prayers admits, but his heart granteth
stanza.couplet: No penetrable entrance to her playning,
“Tears harden luſt, though marble were with rayning.

stanza.line: Her pittie-pleading eyes are ſadlie ﬁxed
In the remorſeleſſe wrinckles of his face.
Her modeſt eloquence with ſighes is mixed,
VVhich to her Oratorie addes more grace.
Shee puts the period oﬅen from his place,
stanza.couplet: And midſt the ſentence ſo her accent breakes,
That twiſe ſhe doth begin ere once ſhe ſpeakes.

stanza.line: She coniures him by high Almightie Ioue,
By knighthood, gentrie, and ſweete friendſhips oth,
By her vntimely teares, her husbands loue,
By holie humaine law, and common troth,
By Heauen and Earth, and all the power of both:
stanza.couplet: That to his borrowed bed he make retire,
And ſtoope to Honor, not to fowle deſire.

stanza.line: Quoth ſhee, reward not Hoſpitalitie,
VVith ſuch black payment, as thou haſt pretended,
Mudde not the fountaine that gaue drinke to thee,
Mar not the thing that cannot be amended.
End thy ill ayme, before thy ſhoote be ended.
stanza.couplet: He is no wood-man that doth bend his bow,
To ſtrike a poore vnſeaſonable Dœ.

stanza.line: My husband is thy friend, for his ſake ſpare me,
Thy ſelfe art mightie, for thine own ſake leaue me;
My ſelfe a weakling, do not then inſnare me.
Thou look’ſt not like deceipt, do not deceiue me.
My ſighes like whirlewindes labor hence to heaue thee.
stanza.couplet: If euer man were mou’d with womās mones,
Be moued with my teares, my ſighes, my grones.

stanza.line: All which together like a troubled Ocean,
Beat at thy rockie, and wracke threatning heart,
To ſoﬅen it with their continuall motion:
For ſtones diſſolu’d to water do conuert.
O if no harder then a ſtone thou art,
stanza.couplet: Melt at my teares and be compaſſionate,
Soﬅ pittie enters at an iron gate.

stanza.line: In Tarqvins likeneſſe I did entertaine thee,
Haſt thou put on his ſhape, to do him ſhame?
To all the Hoſt of Heauen I complaine me.
Thou wrongſt his honor, woūdſt his princely name:
Thou art not what thou ſeem’ſt, and if the ſame,
stanza.couplet: Thou ſeem’ſt not what thou art, a God, a King;
For kings like Gods ſhould gouerne euery thing.

stanza.line: How will thy ſhame be ſeeded in thine age
VVhen thus thy vices bud before thy ſpring?
If in thy hope thou darſt do ſuch outrage,
VVhat dar’ſt thou not when once thou art a King?
O be remembred, no outragious thing
stanza.couplet: From vaſſall aƈtors can be wipt away,
Then Kings miſdeedes cannot be hid in clay.

stanza.line: This deede will make thee only lou’d for feare,
But happie Monarchs ſtill are feard for loue:
VVith fowle offendors thou perforce muſt beare,
VVhen they in thee the like offences proue;
If but for feare of this, thy will remoue.
stanza.couplet: For Princes are the glaſſe, the ſchoole, the booke,
VVhere ſubieƈts eies do learn, do read, do looke.

stanza.line: And wilt thou be the ſchoole where luſt ſhall learne?
Muſt he in thee read leƈtures of ſuch ſhame?
VVilt thou be glaſſe wherein it ſhall diſcerne
Authoritie for ſinne, warrant for blame?
To priuiledge diſhonor in thy name.
stanza.couplet: Thou backſt reproch againſt long-liuing lawd,
And mak’ſt faire reputation but a bawd.

stanza.line: Haſt thou commaund? by him that gaue it thee
From a pure heart commaund thy rebell will:
Draw not thy ſword to gard iniquitie,
For it was lent thee all that broode to kill.
Thy Princelie ofﬁce how canſt thou fulﬁll?
stanza.couplet: VVhen patternd by thy fault fowle ſin may ſay,
He learnd to ſin, and thou didſt teach the way.

stanza.line: Thinke but how vile a ſpeƈtacle it were,
To view thy preſent treſpaſſe in another:
Mens faults do ſeldome to themſelues appeare,
Their own tranſgreſſions partiallie they ſmother,
This guilt would ſeem death-worthie in thy brother.
stanza.couplet: O how are they wrapt in with infamies,
That frō their own miſdeeds askaunce their eyes?

stanza.line: To thee, to thee, my heau’d vp hands appeale,
Not to ſeducing luſt thy raſh relier:
I ſue for exil’d maieſties repeale,
Let him returne, and ﬂattring thoughts retire.
His true reſpeƈt will priſon falſe deſire,
stanza.couplet: And wipe the dim miſt from thy doting eien,
That thou ſhalt ſee thy ſtate, and pittie mine.

stanza.line: Haue done, quoth he, my vncontrolled tide
Turnes not, but ſwels the higher by this let.
Small lightes are ſoone blown out, huge ﬁres abide,
And with the winde in greater furie fret:
The petty ſtreames that paie a dailie det
stanza.couplet: To their ſalt ſoueraigne with their freſh fals haſt,
Adde to his ﬂowe, but alter not his taſt.

stanza.line: Thou art, quoth ſhee, a ſea, a ſoueraigne King,
And lœ there fals into thy boundleſſe ﬂood,
Blacke luſt, diſhonor, ſhame, miſ-gouerning,
VVho ſeeke to ſtaine the Ocean of thy blood.
If all theſe pettie ils ſhall change thy good,
stanza.couplet: Thy ſea within a puddels wombe is herſed,
And not the puddle in thy ſea diſperſed.

stanza.line: So ſhall theſe ſlaues be King, and thou their ſlaue,
Thou noblie baſe, they baſelie digniﬁed:
Thou their faire life, and they thy fowler graue:
Thou lothed in their ſhame, they in thy pride,
The leſſer thing ſhould not the greater hide.
stanza.couplet: The Cedar ſtoopes not to the baſe ſhrubs foote,
But low-ſhrubs wither at the Cedars roote.

stanza.line: So let thy thoughts low vaſſals to thy ſtate,
No more quoth he, by Heauen I will not heare thee.
Yeeld to my loue, if not inforced hate,
In ſteed of loues coy tutch ſhall rudelie teare thee.
That done, deſpitefullie I meane to beare thee
stanza.couplet: Vnto the baſe bed of ſome raſcall groome,
To be thy partner in this ſhamefull doome.

stanza.line: This ſaid, he ſets his foote vppon the light,
For light and luſt are deadlie enemies,
Shame folded vp in blind concealing night,
VVhen moſt vnſeene, then moſt doth tyrannize.
The wolfe hath ceizd his pray, the poor lamb cries,
stanza.couplet: Till with her own white ﬂeece her voice controld,
Intombes her outcrie in her lips ſweet fold.

stanza.line: For with the nightlie linnen that ſhee weares,
He pens her piteous clamors in her head,
Cooling his hot face in the chaſteſt teares,
That euer modeſt eyes with ſorrow ſhed.
O that prone luſt ſhould ſtaine ſo pure a bed,
stanza.couplet: The ſpots whereof could weeping puriﬁe,
Her tears ſhould drop on them perpetuallie.

stanza.line: But ſhee hath loſt a dearer thing then life,
And he hath wonne what he would looſe againe,
This forced league doth force a further ſtrife,
This momentarie ioy breeds months of paine,
This hot deſire conuerts to colde diſdaine;
stanza.couplet: Pure chaſtitie is riﬂed of her ſtore,
And luſt the theefe farre poorer then before.

stanza.line: Looke as the full-fed Hound, or gorged Hawke,
Vnapt for tender ſmell, or ſpeedie ﬂight,
Make ſlow purſuite, or altogether bauk,
The praie wherein by nature they delight:
So ſurfet-taking Tarqvin fares this night:
stanza.couplet: His taſt delicious, in digeſtion ſowring,
Deuoures his will that liu’d by fowle deuouring.

stanza.line: O deeper ſinne then bottomleſſe conceit
Can comprehend in ſtill imagination!
Drunken Deſire muſt vomite his receipt
Ere he can ſee his owne abhomination.
VVhile Luſt is in his pride, no exclamation
stanza.couplet: Can curbe his heat, or reine his raſh deſire,
Till like a Iade, ſelf-will himſelfe doth tire.

stanza.line: And then with lanke, and leane diſcolour’d cheeke,
VVith heauie eye, knit-brow, and ſtrengthleſſe pace,
Feeble deſire all recreant, poore and meeke,
Like to a banckrout beggar wailes his cace:
The ﬂeſh being proud, Deſire doth ﬁght with grace;
stanza.couplet: For there it reuels, and when that decaies,
The guiltie rebell for remiſſion praies.

stanza.line: So fares it with this fault-full Lord of Rome,
VVho this accompliſhment ſo hotly chaſed,
For now againſt himſelfe he ſounds this doome,
That through the length of times he ſtāds diſgraced:
Beſides his ſoules faire temple is defaced,
stanza.couplet: To whoſe weake ruines muſter troopes of cares,
To aske the ſpotted Princeſſe how ſhe fares.

stanza.line: Shee ſayes her ſubieƈts with fowle inſurreƈtion,
Haue batterd downe her conſecrated wall,
And by their mortall fault brought in ſubieƈtion
Her immortalitie, and made her thrall,
To liuing death and payne perpetuall.
stanza.couplet: VVhich in her preſcience ſhe controlled ſtill,
But her foreſight could not foreſtall their will.

stanza.line: Eu’n in this thought through the dark-night he ſtealeth,
A captiue viƈtor that hath loſt in gaine,
Bearing away the wound that nothing healeth,
The ſcarre that will deſpight of Cure remaine,
Leauing his ſpoile perplext in greater paine.
stanza.couplet: Shee beares the lode of luſt he leﬅ behinde,
And he the burthen of a guiltie minde.

stanza.line: Hee like a theeuiſh dog creeps ſadly thence,
Shee like a wearied Lambe lies panting there,
He ſcowles and hates himſelfe for his offence,
Shee deſperat with her nailes her ﬂeſh doth teare.
He faintly ﬂies ſweating with guiltie feare;
stanza.couplet: Shee ſtaies exclayming on the direfull night,
He runnes and chides his vaniſht loth’d delight.

stanza.line: He thence departs a heauy conuertite,
Shee there remaines a hopeleſſe caſt-away,
He in his ſpeed lookes for the morning light:
Shee prayes ſhee neuer may behold the day.
For daie, quoth ſhee, nights ſcapes doth open lay,
stanza.couplet: And my true eyes haue neuer praƈtiz’d how
To cloake offences with a cunning brow.

stanza.line: They thinke not but that euerie eye can ſee,
The ſame diſgrace which they themſelues behold:
And therefore would they ſtill in darkeneſſe be,
To haue their vnſeene ſinne remaine vntold.
For they their guilt with weeping will vnfold,
stanza.couplet: And graue like water that doth eate in ſteele,
Vppon my cheeks, what helpeleſſe ſhame I feele.

stanza.line: Here ſhee exclaimes againſt repoſe and reſt,
And bids her eyes hereaﬅer ſtill be blinde,
Shee wakes her heart by beating on her breſt,
And bids it leape from thence, where it maie ﬁnde
Some purer cheſt, to cloſe ſo pure a minde.
stanza.couplet: Franticke with griefe thus breaths ſhee forth her ſpite,
Againſt the vnſeene ſecrecie of night.

stanza.line: O comfort killing night, image of Hell,
Dim regiſter, and notarie of ſhame,
Blacke ſtage for tragedies, and murthers fell,
Vaſt ſin-concealing Chaos, nourſe of blame.
Blinde mufﬂed bawd, darke harber for defame,
stanza.couplet: Grim caue of death, whiſpring conſpirator,
VVith cloſe-tong’d treaſon & the rauiſher.

stanza.line: O hatefull, vaporous, and foggy night,
Since thou art guilty of my cureleſſe crime:
Muſter thy miſts to meete the Eaſterne light,
Make war againſt proportion’d courſe of time.
Or if thou wilt permit the Sunne to clime
stanza.couplet: His wonted height, yet ere he go to bed,
Knit poyſonous clouds about his golden head.

stanza.line: VVith rotten damps rauiſh the morning aire,
Let their exhald vnholdſome breaths make ſicke
The life of puritie, the ſupreme faire,
Ere he arriue his wearie noone-tide pricke,
And let thy muſtie vapours march ſo thicke,
stanza.couplet: That in their ſmoakie rankes, his ſmothred light
May ſet at noone, and make perpetuall night.

stanza.line: VVere Tarqvin night, as he is but nights child,
The ſiluer-ſhining Queene he would diſtaine;
Her twinckling handmaids to (by him deﬁl’d)
Through nights black boſom ſhuld not peep again.
So ſhould I haue copartners in my paine,
stanza.couplet: And fellowſhip in wœ doth wœ aſſwage,
As Palmers chat makes ſhort their pilgrimage.

stanza.line: VVhere now I haue no one to bluſh with me,
To croſſe their armes & hang their heads with mine,
To maske their browes and hide their infamie,
But I alone, alone muſt ſit and pine,
Seaſoning the earth with ſhowres of ſiluer brine;
stanza.couplet: Mingling my talk with tears, my greef with grones,
Poore waſting monuments of laſting mones.

stanza.line: O night thou furnace of fowle reeking ſmoke!
Let not the iealous daie behold that face,
VVhich vnderneath thy blacke all hiding cloke
Immodeſtly lies martird with diſgrace.
Keepe ſtill poſſeſſion of thy gloomy place,
stanza.couplet: That all the faults which in thy raigne are made,
May likewiſe be ſepulcherd in thy ſhade.

stanza.line: Make me not obieƈt to the tell-tale day,
The light will ſhew charaƈterd in my brow,
The ſtorie of ſweete chaſtities decay,
The impious breach of holy wedlocke vowe.
Yea the illiterate that know not how
stanza.couplet: To cipher what is writ in learned bookes,
VVill cote my lothſome treſpaſſe in my lookes.

stanza.line: The nourſe to ſtill her child will tell my ſtorie,
And fright her crying babe with Tarqvins name.
The Orator to decke his oratorie,
VVill couple my reproch to Tarqvins ſhame.
Feaſt-ﬁnding minſtrels tuning my defame,
stanza.couplet: VVill tie the hearers to attend ech line,
How Tarqvin wronged me, I Colatine .

stanza.line: Let my good name, that ſenceleſſe reputation,
For Colatines deare loue be kept vnſpotted:
If that be made a theame for diſputation,
The branches of another roote are rotted;
And vndeſeru’d reproch to him alotted,
stanza.couplet: That is as cleare from this attaint of mine,
As I ere this was pure to Colatine.

stanza.line: O vnſeene ſhame, inuiſible diſgrace,
O vnfelt ſore, creſt-wounding priuat ſcarre!
Reproch is ſtampt in Colatinvs face,
And Tarqvins eye maie read the mot a farre,
“How he in peace is wounded not in warre.
stanza.couplet: “Alas how manie beare ſuch ſhamefull blowes,
VVhich not thēſelues but he that giues thē knowes.

stanza.line: If Colatine , thine honor laie in me,
From me by ſtrong aſſault it is bereﬅ:
My Honnie loſt, and I a Drone-like Bee,
Haue no perfeƈtion of my ſommer leﬅ,
But rob’d and ranſak’t by iniurious theﬅ.
stanza.couplet: In thy weake Hiue a wandring waſpe hath crept,
And ſuck’t the Honnie which thy chaſt Bee kept.

stanza.line: Yet am I guiltie of thy Honors wracke,
Yet for thy Honor did I entertaine him,
Comming from thee I could not put him backe:
For it had beene diſhonor to diſdaine him,
Beſides of wearineſſe he did complaine him,
stanza.couplet: And talk’t of Vertue ( O vnlook’t for euill,)
VVhen Vertue is prophan’d in ſuch a Deuill.

stanza.line: VVhy ſhould the worme intrude the maiden bud?
Or hatefull Kuckcowes hatch in Sparrows neſts?
Or Todes infeƈt faire founts with venome mud?
Or tyrant follie lurke in gentle breſts?
Or Kings be breakers of their owne beheſtes?
stanza.couplet: “But no perfeƈtion is ſo abſolute,
That ſome impuritie doth not pollute.

stanza.line: The aged man that coffers vp his gold,
Is plagu’d with cramps, and gouts, and painefull ﬁts,
And ſcarce hath eyes his treaſure to behold,
But like ſtill pining Tantalvs he ſits,
And vſeleſſe barnes the harueſt of his wits:
stanza.couplet: Hauing no other pleaſure of his gaine,
But torment that it cannot cure his paine.

stanza.line: So then he hath it when he cannot vſe it,
And leaues it to be maiſtred by his yong:
VVho in their pride do preſently abuſe it,
Their father was too weake, and they too ſtrong
To hold their curſed-bleſſed Fortune long.
stanza.couplet: “The ſweets we wiſh for, turne to lothed ſowrs,
“Euen in the moment that we call them ours.

stanza.line: Vnruly blaſts wait on the tender ſpring,
Vnholſome weeds take roote with precious ﬂowrs,
The Adder hiſſes where the ſweete birds ſing,
VVhat Vertue breedes Iniquity deuours:
VVe haue no good that we can ſay is ours,
stanza.couplet: But ill annexed opportunity
Or kils his life, or elſe his quality.

stanza.line: O opportunity thy guilt is great,
Tis thou that execut’ſt the traytors treaſon:
Thou ſets the wolfe where he the lambe may get,
VVho euer plots the ſinne thou pointſt the ſeaſon.
Tis thou that ſpurn’ſt at right, at law, at reaſon,
stanza.couplet: And in thy ſhadie Cell where none may ſpie him,
Sits ſin to ceaze the ſoules that wander by him.

stanza.line: Thou makeſt the veſtall violate her oath,
Thou bloweſt the ﬁre when temperance is thawd,
Thou ſmotherſt honeſtie, thou murthreſt troth,
Thou fowle abbettor, thou notorious bawd,
Thou planteſt ſcandal, and diſplaceſt laud.
stanza.couplet: Thou rauiſher, thou traytor, thou falſe theefe,
Thy honie turnes to gall, thy ioy to greefe.

stanza.line: Thy ſecret pleaſure turnes to open ſhame,
Thy priuate feaſting to a publicke faſt,
Thy ſmoothing titles to a ragged name,
Thy ſugred tongue to bitter wormwood taſt,
Thy violent vanities can neuer laſt.
stanza.couplet: How comes it then, vile opportunity
Being ſo bad, ſuch numbers ſeeke for thee?

stanza.line: VVhen wilt thou be the humble ſuppliants friend
And bring him where his ſuit may be obtained?
VVhen wilt thou ſort an howre great ſtrifes to end?
Or free that ſoule which wretchednes hath chained?
Giue phiſicke to the ſicke, eaſe to the pained?
stanza.couplet: The poore, lame, blind, hault, creepe, cry out for thee,
But they nere meet with opportunitie.

stanza.line: The patient dies while the Phiſitian ſleepes,
The Orphane pines while the oppreſſor feedes.
Iuſtice is feaſting while the widow weepes.
Aduiſe is ſporting while infeƈtion breeds.
Thou graunt’ſt no time for charitable deeds.
stanza.couplet: VVrath, enuy, treaſon, rape, and murthers rages,
Thy heinous houres wait on them as their Pages.

stanza.line: VVhen Trueth and Vertue haue to do with thee,
A thouſand croſſes keepe them from thy aide:
They buie thy helpe, but ſinne nere giues a fee,
He gratis comes, and thou art well apaide,
As well to heare, as graunt what he hath ſaide.
stanza.couplet: My Colatine would elſe haue come to me,
VVhen Tarqvin did, but he was ſtaied by thee.

stanza.line: Guilty thou art of murther, and of theﬅ,
Guilty of periurie, and ſubornation,
Guilty of treaſon, forgerie, and ſhiﬅ,
Guilty of inceſt that abhomination,
An acceſſarie by thine inclination.
stanza.couplet: To all ſinnes paſt and all that are to come,
From the creation to the generall doome.

stanza.line: Miſſhapen time, copeſmate of vgly night,
Swiﬅ ſubtle poſt, carrier of grieſlie care,
Eater of youth, falſe ſlaue to falſe delight:
Baſe watch of wœs, ſins packhorſe, vertues ſnare.
Thou nourſeſt all, and murthreſt all that are.
stanza.couplet: O heare me then, iniurious ſhiﬅing time,
Be guiltie of my death ſince of my crime.

stanza.line: VVhy hath thy ſeruant opportunity
Betraide the howres thou gau’ſt me to repoſe?
Canceld my fortunes, and inchained me
To endleſſe date of neuer-ending wœs?
Times ofﬁce is to ﬁne the hate of fœs,
stanza.couplet: To eate vp errours by opinion bred,
Not ſpend the dowrie of a lawfull bed.

stanza.line: Times glorie is to calme contending Kings,
To vnmaske falſhood, and bring truth to light,
To ſtampe the ſeale of time in aged things,
To wake the morne, and Centinell the night,
To wrong the wronger till he render right,
stanza.couplet: To ruinate proud buildings with thy howres,
And ſmeare with duſt their glitring golden towrs.

stanza.line: To ﬁll with worme-holes ſtately monuments,
To feede obliuion with decay of things,
To blot old bookes, and alter their contents,
To plucke the quils from auncient rauens wings,
To drie the old oakes ſappe, and cheriſh ſprings:
stanza.couplet: To ſpoile Antiquities of hammerd ſteele,
And turne the giddy round of Fortunes wheele.

stanza.line: To ſhew the beldame daughters of her daughter,
To make the child a man, the man a childe,
To ſlay the tygre that doth liue by ſlaughter,
To tame the Vnicorne, and Lion wild,
To mocke the ſubtle in themſelues beguild,
stanza.couplet: To cheare the Plowman with increaſefull crops,
And waſt huge ſtones with little water drops.

stanza.line: VVhy work’ſt thou miſchiefe in thy Pilgrimage,
Vnleſſe thou could’ſt returne to make amends?
One poore retyring minute in an age
VVould purchaſe thee a thouſand thouſand friends,
Lending him wit that to bad detters lends,
stanza.couplet: O this dread night, would’ſt thou one howr come backe,
I could preuent this ſtorme, and ſhun thy wracke.

stanza.line: Thou ceaſeleſſe lackie to Eternitie,
VVith ſome miſchance croſſe Tarqvin in his ﬂight.
Deuiſe extreames beyond extremitie,
To make him curſe this curſed crimefull night:
Let gaſtly ſhadowes his lewd eyes affright,
stanza.couplet: And the dire thought of his committed euill,
Shape euerie buſh a hideous ſhapeleſſe deuill.

stanza.line: Diſturbe his howres of reſt with reſtleſſe trances,
Afﬂiƈt him in his bed with bedred grones,
Let there bechaunce him pitifull miſchances,
To make him mone, but pitie not his mones:
Stone him with hardned hearts harder then ſtones,
stanza.couplet: And let milde women to him looſe their mildneſſe,
VVilder to him then Tygers in their wildneſſe.

stanza.line: Let him haue time to teare his curled haire,
Let him haue time againſt himſelfe to raue,
Let him haue time of times helpe to deſpaire,
Let him haue time to liue a lothed ſlaue,
Let him haue time a beggers orts to craue,
stanza.couplet: And time to ſee one that by almes doth liue,
Diſdaine to him diſdained ſcraps to giue.

stanza.line: Let him haue time to ſee his friends his fœs,
And merrie fooles to mocke at him reſort:
Let him haue time to marke how ſlow time gœs
In time of ſorrow, and how ſwiﬅ and ſhort
His time of follie, and his time of ſport.
stanza.couplet: And euer let his vnrecalling crime
Haue time to waile th’abuſing of his time.

stanza.line: O time thou tutor both to good and bad,
Teach me to curſe him that thou taught’ſt this ill:
At his owne ſhadow let the theefe runne mad,
Himſelfe, himſelfe ſeeke euerie howre to kill,
Such wretched hāds ſuch wretched blood ſhuld ſpill.
stanza.couplet: For who ſo baſe would ſuch an ofﬁce haue,
As ſclandrous deaths-man to ſo baſe a ſlaue.

stanza.line: The baſer is he coming from a King,
To ſhame his hope with deedes degenerate,
The mightier man the mightier is the thing
That makes him honord, or begets him hate:
For greateſt ſcandall waits on greateſt ſtate.
stanza.couplet: The Moone being clouded, preſently is miſt,
But little ſtars may hide them when they liſt.

stanza.line: The Crow may bath his coaleblacke wings in mire,
And vnperceau’d ﬂie with the ﬁlth away,
But if the like the ſnow-white Swan deſire,
The ſtaine vppon his ſiluer Downe will ſtay.
Poore grooms are ſightles night, kings glorious day,
stanza.couplet: Gnats are vnnoted whereſœre they ﬂie,
But Eagles gaz’d vppon with euerie eye.

stanza.line: Out idle wordes, ſeruants to ſhallow fooles,
Vnproﬁtable ſounds, weake arbitrators,
Buſie your ſelues in skill contending ſchooles,
Debate where leyſure ſerues with dull debators:
To trembling Clients be you mediators,
stanza.couplet: For me, I force not argument a ſtraw,
Since that my caſe is paſt the helpe of law.

stanza.line: In vaine I raile at oportunitie,
At time, at Tarqvin, and vnchearfull night,
In vaine I cauill with mine infamie,
In vaine I ſpurne at my conﬁrm’d deſpight,
This helpleſſe ſmoake of words doth me no right:
stanza.couplet: The remedie indeede to do me good,
Is to let forth my fowle deﬁled blood.

stanza.line: Poore hand why quiuerſt thou at this decree?
Honor thy ſelfe to rid me of this ſhame,
For if I die, my Honor liues in thee,
But if I liue thou liu’ſt in my defame;
Since thou couldſt not defend thy loyall Dame,
stanza.couplet: And waſt affeard to ſcratch her wicked Fo,
Kill both thy ſelfe, and her for yeelding ſo.

stanza.line: This ſaid, from her betumbled couch ſhe ſtarteth,
To ﬁnd ſome deſp’rat Inſtrument of death,
But this no ſlaughter houſe no toole imparteth,
To make more vent for paſſage of her breath,
VVhich thronging through her lips ſo vaniſheth,
stanza.couplet: As ſmoake from Ætna, that in aire conſumes,
Or that which from diſcharged Cannon fumes.

stanza.line: In vaine (quoth ſhee) I liue, and ſeeke in vaine
Some happie meane to end a hapleſſe life.
I fear’d by Tarqvins Fauchion to be ſlaine,
Yet for the ſelfe ſame purpoſe ſeeke a knife;
But when I fear’d I was a loyall wife,
stanza.couplet: So am I now, ô no that cannot be,
Of that true tipe hath Tarqvin riﬂed me.

stanza.line: O that is gone for which I ſought to liue,
And therefore now I need not feare to die,
To cleare this ſpot by death (at leaſt) I giue
A badge of Fame to ſclanders liuerie,
A dying life, to liuing infamie:
stanza.couplet: Poore helpleſſe helpe, the treaſure ſtol’ne away,
To burne the guiltleſſe casket where it lay.

stanza.line: VVell well deare Colatine , thou ſhalt not know
The ſtained taſt of violated troth:
I will not wrong thy true affeƈtion ſo,
To ﬂatter thee with an infringed oath:
This baſtard graffe ſhall neuer come to growth,
stanza.couplet: He ſhall not boaſt who did thy ſtocke pollute,
That thou art doting father of his fruite.

stanza.line: Nor ſhall he ſmile at thee in ſecret thought,
Nor laugh with his companions at thy ſtate,
But thou ſhalt know thy intreſt was not bought
Baſely with gold, but ſtolne from foorth thy gate.
For me I am the miſtreſſe of my fate,
stanza.couplet: And with my treſpaſſe neuer will diſpence,
Till life to death acquit my forſt offence.

stanza.line: I will not poyſon thee with my attaint,
Nor fold my fault in cleanly coin’d excuſes;
My ſable ground of ſinne I will not paint,
To hide the truth of this falſe nights abuſes.
My tongue ſhall vtter all, mine eyes like ſluces,
stanza.couplet: As from a mountaine ſpring that feeds a dale,
Shal guſh pure ſtreams to purge my impure tale.

stanza.line: By this lamenting Philomele had ended
The well-tun’d warble of her nightly ſorrow,
And ſolemne night with ſlow ſad gate deſcended
To ouglie Hell, when lœ the bluſhing morrow
Lends light to all faire eyes that light will borrow.
stanza.couplet: But cloudie Lvcrece ſhames her ſelfe to ſee,
And therefore ſtill in night would cloiſtred be.

stanza.line: Reuealing day through euery crannie ſpies,
And ſeems to point her out where ſhe ſits weeping,
To whom ſhee ſobbing ſpeakes, ô eye of eyes,
VVhy pry’ſt thou throgh my window? leaue thy peeping,
Mock with thy tickling beams, eies that are ſleeping;
stanza.couplet: Brand not my forehead with thy percing light,
For day hath nought to do what’s done by night.

stanza.line: Thus cauils ſhee with euerie thing ſhee ſees:
True griefe is fond and teſtie as a childe,
VVho wayward once, his mood with naught agrees,
Old wœs, not infant ſorrowes beare them milde,
Continuance tames the one, the other wilde,
stanza.couplet: Like an vnpraƈtiz’d ſwimmer plunging ſtill,
VVith too much labour drowns for want of skill.

stanza.line: So ſhee deepe drenched in a Sea of care,
Holds diſputation with ech thing ſhee vewes,
And to her ſelfe all ſorrow doth compare,
No obieƈt but her paſſions ſtrength renewes:
And as one ſhiﬅes another ſtraight inſewes,
stanza.couplet: Sometime her griefe is dumbe and hath no words,
Sometime tis mad and too much talke affords.

stanza.line: The little birds that tune their mornings ioy,
Make her mones mad, with their ſweet melodie,
“For mirth doth ſearch the bottome of annoy,
“Sad ſoules are ſlaine in merrie companie,
“Griefe beſt is pleaſ’d with griefes ſocietie;
stanza.couplet: “True ſorrow then is feelinglie ſufﬁz’d,
“VVhen with like ſemblance it is ſimpathiz’d.

stanza.line: “Tis double death to drowne in ken of ſhore,
“He ten times pines, that pines beholding food,
“To ſee the ſalue doth make the wound ake more:
“Great griefe greeues moſt at that wold do it good;
“Deepe wœs roll forward like a gentle ﬂood,
stanza.couplet: VVho being ſtopt, the boūding banks oreﬂowes,
Griefe dallied with, nor law, nor limit knowes.

stanza.line: You mocking Birds (quoth ſhe) your tunes intombe
VVithin your hollow ſwelling feathered breaſts,
And in my hearing be you mute and dumbe,
My reſtleſſe diſcord loues no ſtops nor reſts:
“A wœfull Hoſteſſe brookes not merrie gueſts.
stanza.couplet: Reliſh your nimble notes to pleaſing eares,
“Diſtres likes dūps whē time is kept with teares.

stanza.line: Come Philomele that ſing’ſt of rauiſhment,
Make thy ſad groue in my diſheueld heare,
As the danke earth weepes at thy languiſhment:
So I at each ſad ſtraine, will ſtraine a teare,
And with deepe grones the Diapaſon beare:
stanza.couplet: For burthen-wiſe ile hum on Tarqvin ſtill,
VVhile thou on Terevs deſcants better skill.

stanza.line: And whiles againſt a thorne thou bear’ſt thy part,
To keepe thy ſharpe wœs waking, wretched I
To imitate thee well, againſt my heart
VVill ﬁxe a ſharpe knife to affright mine eye,
VVho if it winke ſhall thereon fall and die.
stanza.couplet: Theſe meanes as frets vpon an inſtrument,
Shal tune our heart-ſtrings to true languiſhment.

stanza.line: And for poore bird thou ſing’ſt not in the day,
As ſhaming any eye ſhould thee behold:
Some darke deepe deſert ſeated from the way,
That knowes not parching heat, nor freezing cold
VVill wee ﬁnd out: and there we will vnfold
stanza.couplet: To creatures ſtern, ſad tunes to change their kinds,
Since mē proue beaſts, let beaſts bear gētle minds.

stanza.line: As the poore frighted Deare that ſtands at gaze,
VVildly determining which way to ﬂie,
Or one incompaſt with a winding maze,
That cannot tread the way out readilie:
So with her ſelfe is ſhee in mutinie,
stanza.couplet: To liue or die which of the twaine were better,
VVhen life is ſham’d and death reproches detter.

stanza.line: To kill my ſelfe, quoth ſhee, alacke what were it,
But with my body my poore ſoules polluſion?
They that looſe halfe with greater patience beare it,
Then they whoſe whole is ſwallowed in confuſion.
That mother tries a mercileſſe concluſion,
stanza.couplet: VVho hauing two ſweet babes, when death takes one,
VVill ſlay the other, and be nurſe to none.

stanza.line: My bodie or my ſoule which was the dearer?
VVhen the one pure, the other made diuine,
VVhoſe loue of eyther to my ſelfe was nearer?
VVhen both were kept for Heauen and Colatine :
Ay me, the Barke pild from the loﬅie Pine,
stanza.couplet: His leaues will wither, and his ſap decay,
So muſt my ſoule her barke being pild away.

stanza.line: Her houſe is ſackt, her quiet interrupted,
Her manſion batterd by the enemie,
Her ſacred temple ſpotted, ſpoild, corrupted,
Groſlie ingirt with daring infamie.
Then let it not be cald impietie,
stanza.couplet: If in this blemiſht fort I make ſome hole,
Through which I may conuay this troubled ſoule.

stanza.line: Yet die I will not, till my Colatine
Haue heard the cauſe of my vntimelie death,
That he may vow in that ſad houre of mine,
Reuenge on him that made me ſtop my breath,
My ſtained bloud to Tarqvin ile bequeath,
stanza.couplet: VVhich by him tāinted, ſhall for him be ſpent,
And as his due writ in my teſtament.

stanza.line: My Honor ile bequeath vnto the knife
That wounds my bodie ſo diſhonored,
Tis Honor to depriue diſhonord life,
The one will liue, the other being dead.
So of ſhames aſhes ſhall my Fame be bred,
stanza.couplet: For in my death I murther ſhamefull ſcorne,
My ſhame ſo dead, mine honor is new borne.

stanza.line: Deare Lord of that deare iewell I haue loſt,
VVhat legacie ſhall I bequeath to thee?
My reſolution loue ſhall be thy boſt,
By whoſe example thou reueng’d mayſt be.
How Tarqvin muſt be vſ’d, read it in me,
stanza.couplet: My ſelfe thy friend will kill my ſelfe thy fo,
And for my ſake ſerue thou falſe Tarqvin ſo.

stanza.line: This briefe abridgement of my will I make,
My ſoule and bodie to the skies and ground:
My reſolution Husband dœ thou take,
Mine Honor be the knifes that makes my wound,
My ſhame be his that did my Fame confound;
stanza.couplet: And all my Fame that liues disburſed be,
To thoſe that liue and thinke no ſhame of me.

stanza.line: Thou Colatine ſhalt ouerſee this will,
How was I ouerſeene that thou ſhalt ſee it?
My bloud ſhall waſh the ſclander of mine ill,
My liues foule deed, my lifes faire end ſhall free it.
Faint not faint heart, but ſtoutlie ſay ſo be it,
stanza.couplet: Yeeld to my hand, my hand ſhall conquer thee,
Thou dead, both die, and both ſhall viƈtors be.

stanza.line: This plot of death when ſadlie ſhee had layd,
And wip’t the briniſh pearle from her bright eies,
VVith vntun’d tongue ſhee hoarſlie cals her mayd,
VVhoſe ſwiﬅ obedience to her miſtreſſe hies.
“For ﬂeet-wing’d duetie with thoghts feathers ﬂies,
stanza.couplet: Poore Lvcrece cheeks vnto her maid ſeem ſo,
As winter meads when ſun doth melt their ſnow.

stanza.line: Her miſtreſſe ſhee doth giue demure good morrow,
VVith ſoﬅ ſlow-tongue, true marke of modeſtie,
And ſorts a ſad looke to her Ladies ſorrow,
(For why her face wore ſorrowes liuerie.)
But durſt not aske of her audaciouſlie,
stanza.couplet: VVhy her two ſuns were clowd ecclipſed ſo,
Nor why her faire cheeks ouer-waſht with wœ.

stanza.line: But as the earth doth weepe the Sun being ſet,
Each ﬂowre moiſtned like a melting eye:
Euen ſo the maid with ſwelling drops gan wet
Her circled eien inforſt, by ſimpathie
Of thoſe faire Suns ſet in her miſtreſſe skie,
stanza.couplet: VVho in a ſalt wau’d Ocean quench their light,
VVhich makes the maid weep like the dewy night.

stanza.line: A prettie while theſe prettie creatures ſtand,
Like Iuorie conduits corall ceſterns ﬁlling:
One iuſtlie weepes, the other takes in hand
No cauſe, but companie of her drops ſpilling.
Their gentle ſex to weepe are oﬅen willing,
stanza.couplet: Greeuing themſelues to geſſe at others ſmarts,
And thē they drown their eies, or break their harts.

stanza.line: For men haue marble, women waxen mindes,
And therefore are they form’d as marble will,
The weake oppreſt, th’impreſſion of ſtrange kindes
Is form’d in them by force, by fraud, or skill.
Then call them not the Authors of their ill,
stanza.couplet: No more then waxe ſhall be accounted euill,
VVherein is ſtampt the ſemblance of a Deuill.

stanza.line: Their ſmoothneſſe; like a goodly champaine plaine,
Laies open all the little wormes that creepe,
In men as in a rough-growne groue remaine.
Caue-keeping euils that obſcurely ſleepe.
Through chriſtall wals ech little mote will peepe,
stanza.couplet: Though mē cā couer crimes with bold ſtern looks,
Poore womens faces are their owne faults books.

stanza.line: No man inueigh againſt the withered ﬂowre,
But chide rough winter that the ﬂowre hath kild,
Not that deuour’d, but that which doth deuour
Is worthie blame, ô let it not be hild
Poore womens faults, that they are ſo fulﬁld
stanza.couplet: VVith mens abuſes, thoſe proud Lords to blame,
Make weak-made womē tenants to their ſhame.

stanza.line: The preſident whereof in Lvcrece view,
Aſſail’d by night with circumſtances ſtrong
Of preſent death, and ſhame that might inſue.
By that her death to do her husband wrong,
Such danger to reſiſtance did belong:
stanza.couplet: That dying feare through all her bodie ſpred,
And who cannot abuſe a bodie dead?

stanza.line: By this milde patience bid faire Lvcrece ſpeake,
To the poore counterfaite of her complayning,
My girle, quoth ſhee, on what occaſion breake
Thoſe tears frō thee, that downe thy cheeks are raigning?
If thou doſt weepe for griefe of my ſuſtaining:
stanza.couplet: Know gentle wench it ſmall auailes my mood,
If tears could help, mine own would do me good.

stanza.line: But tell me girle, when went (and there ſhee ſtaide,
Till aﬅer a deepe grone) Tarqvin from hence,
Madame ere I was vp (repli’d the maide,)
The more to blame my ſluggard negligence.
Yet with the fault I thus farre can diſpence:
stanza.couplet: My ſelfe was ſtirring ere the breake of day,
And ere I roſe was Tarqvin gone away.

stanza.line: But Lady, if your maide may be ſo bold,
Shee would requeſt to know your heauineſſe:
(O peace quoth Lvcrece) if it ſhould be told,
The repetition cannot make it leſſe:
For more it is, then I can well expreſſe,
stanza.couplet: And that deepe torture may be cal’d a Hell,
VVhen more is felt then one hath power to tell.

stanza.line: Go get mee hither paper, inke, and pen,
Yet ſaue that labour, for I haue them heare,
(VVhat ſhould I ſay) one of my husbands men
Bid thou be readie, by and by, to beare
A letter to my Lord, my Loue, my Deare,
stanza.couplet: Bid him with ſpeede prepare to carrie it,
The cauſe craues haſt, and it will ſoone be writ.

stanza.line: Her maide is gone, and ſhee prepares to write,
Firſt houering ore the paper with her quill:
Conceit and griefe an eager combat ﬁght,
VVhat wit ſets downe is blotted ſtraight with will.
This is too curious good, this blunt and ill,
stanza.couplet: Much like a preſſe of people at a dore,
Throng her inuentions which ſhall go before.

stanza.line: At laſt ſhee thus begins: thou worthie Lord,
Of that vnworthie wife that greeteth thee,
Health to thy perſon, next, vouchſafe t’afford
(If euer loue, thy Lvcrece thou wilt ſee,)
Some preſent ſpeed, to come and viſite me:
stanza.couplet: So I commend me, from our houſe in griefe,
My wœs are tedious, though my words are briefe.

stanza.line: Here folds ſhee vp the tenure of her wœ,
Her certaine ſorrow writ vncertainely,
By this ſhort Cedule Colatine may know
Her griefe, but not her griefes true quality,
Shee dares not thereof make diſcouery,
stanza.couplet: Leſt he ſhould hold it her own groſſe abuſe,
Ere ſhe with bloud had ſtain’d her ſtain’d excuſe.

stanza.line: Beſides the life and feeling of her paſſion,
Shee hoords to ſpend, when he is by to heare her,
VVhen ſighs, & grones, & tears may grace the faſhiō
Of her diſgrace, the better ſo to cleare her
From that ſuſpiciō which the world might bear her.
stanza.couplet: To ſhun this blot, ſhee would not blot the letter
VVith words, till aƈtion might becom thē better.

stanza.line: To ſee ſad ſights, moues more then heare them told,
For then the eye interpretes to the eare
The heauie motion that it doth behold,
VVhen euerie part, a part of wœ doth beare.
Tis but a part of ſorrow that we heare,
stanza.couplet: Deep ſounds make leſſer noiſe thē ſhallow foords,
And ſorrow ebs, being blown with wind of words.

stanza.line: Her letter now is ſeal’d, and on it writ
At Ardea to my Lord with more then haſt,
The Poſt attends, and ſhee deliuers it,
Charging the ſowr-fac’d groome, to high as faſt
As lagging fowles before the Northerne blaſts,
stanza.couplet: Speed more then ſpeed, but dul & ſlow ſhe deems,
Extremity ſtill vrgeth ſuch extremes.

stanza.line: The homelie villaine curſies to her low,
And bluſhing on her with a ſtedfaſt eye,
Receaues the ſcroll without or yea or no,
And forth with baſhfull innocence doth hie.
But they whoſe guilt within their boſomes lie,
stanza.couplet: Imagine euerie eye beholds their blame,
For Lvcrece thought, he bluſht to ſee her ſhame.

stanza.line: VVhen ſeelie Groome (God wot) it was defeƈt
Of ſpirite, life, and bold audacitie,
Such harmleſſe creatures haue a true reſpeƈt
To talke in deeds, while others ſaucilie
Promiſe more ſpeed, but do it leyſurelie.
stanza.couplet: Euen ſo this patterne of the worne-out age,
Pawn’d honeſt looks, but laid no words to gage.

stanza.line: His kindled duetie kindled her miſtruſt,
That two red ﬁres in both their faces blazed,
Shee thought he bluſht, as knowing Tarqvins luſt,
And bluſhing with him, wiſtlie on him gazed,
Her earneſt eye did make him more amazed.
stanza.couplet: The more ſhee ſaw the bloud his cheeks repleniſh,
The more ſhee thought he ſpied in her ſom blemiſh.

stanza.line: But long ſhe thinkes till he returne againe,
And yet the dutious vaſſall ſcarce is gone,
The wearie time ſhee cannot entertaine,
For now tis ſtale to ſigh, to weepe, and grone,
So wœ hath wearied wœ, mone tired mone,
stanza.couplet: That ſhee her plaints a little while doth ſtay,
Pawſing for means to mourne ſome newer way.

stanza.line: At laſt ſhee cals to mind where hangs a peece
Of skilfull painting, made for Priams Troy,
Before the which is drawn the power of Greece,
For Helens rape, the Cittie to deſtroy,
Threatning cloud-kiſſing Illion with annoy,
stanza.couplet: VVhich the conceipted Painter drew ſo prowd,
As Heauen (it ſeemd) to kiſſe the turrets bow’d.

stanza.line: A thouſand lamentable obieƈts there,
In ſcorne of Nature, Art gaue liueleſſe life,
Many a dry drop ſeem’d a weeping teare,
Shed for the ſlaughtred husband by the wife.
The red bloud reek’d to ſhew the Painters ſtrife,
stanza.couplet: And dying eyes gleem’d forth their aſhie lights,
Like dying coales burnt out in tedious nights.

stanza.line: There might you ſee the labouring Pyoner
Begrim’d with ſweat, and ſmeared all with duſt,
And from the towres of Troy, there would appeare
The verie eyes of men through loop-holes thruſt,
Gazing vppon the Greekes with little luſt,
stanza.couplet: Such ſweet obſeruance in this worke was had,
That one might ſee thoſe farre of eyes looke ſad.

stanza.line: In great commaunders, Grace and Maieſtie,
You might behold triumphing in their faces;
In youth quick-bearing and dexteritie,
And here and there the Painter interlaces
Pale cowards marching on with trembling paces.
stanza.couplet: VVhich hartleſſe peaſaunts did ſo wel reſemble,
That one would ſwear he ſaw them quake & trēble.

stanza.line: In Aiax and Vlysses, ô what Art
Of Phiſiognomy might one behold!
The face of eyther cypher’d eythers heart,
Their face, their manners moſt expreſlie told,
In Aiax eyes blunt rage and rigour rold,
stanza.couplet: But the mild glance that ſlie Vlysses lent,
Shewed deepe regard and ſmiling gouernment.

stanza.line: There pleading might you ſee graue Nestor ſtand,
As’twere incouraging the Greekes to ﬁght,
Making ſuch ſober aƈtion with his hand,
That it beguild attention, charm’d the ſight,
In ſpeech it ſeemd his beard, all ſiluer white,
stanza.couplet: VVag’d vp and downe, and from his lips did ﬂie,
Thin winding breath which purl’d vp to the skie.

stanza.line: About him were a preſſe of gaping faces,
VVhich ſeem’d to ſwallow vp his ſound aduice,
All ioyntlie liſtning, but with ſeuerall graces,
As if ſome Marmaide did their eares intice,
Some high, ſome low, the Painter was ſo nice.
stanza.couplet: The ſcalpes of manie, almoſt hid behind,
To iump vp higher ſeem’d to mocke the mind.

stanza.line: Here one mans hand leand on anothers head,
His noſe being ſhadowed by his neighbours eare,
Here one being throng’d, bears back all boln, & red,
Another ſmotherd, ſeemes to pelt and ſweare,
And in their rage ſuch ſignes of rage they beare,
stanza.couplet: As but for loſſe of Nestors golden words,
It ſeem’d they would debate with angrie ſwords.

stanza.line: For much imaginarie worke was there,
Conceipt deceitfull, ſo compaƈt ſo kinde,
That for Achilles image ſtood his ſpeare
Grip’t in an Armed hand, himſelfe behind
VVas leﬅ vnſeene, ſaue to the eye of mind,
stanza.couplet: A hand, a foote, a face, a leg, a head
Stood for the whole to be imagined.

stanza.line: And from the wals of ſtrong beſieged Troy,
VVhen their braue hope, bold Heƈtor march’d to ﬁeld,
Stood manie Troian mothers ſharing ioy,
To ſee their youthfull ſons bright weapons wield,
And to their hope they ſuch odde aƈtion yeeld,
stanza.couplet: That through their light ioy ſeemed to appeare,
(Like bright things ſtaind) a kind of heauie feare.

stanza.line: And from the ſtrond of Dardan where they fought,
To Simois reedie bankes the red bloud ran,
VVhoſe waues to imitate the battaile ſought
VVith ſwelling ridges, and their rankes began
To breake vppon the galled ſhore, and than
stanza.couplet: Retire againe, till meeting greater ranckes,
They ioine, & ſhoot their fome at Simois bancks.

stanza.line: To this well painted peece is Lvcrece come,
To ﬁnd a face where all diſtreſſe is ſteld.
Manie ſhee ſees, where cares haue carued ſome,
But none where all diſtreſſe and dolor dweld,
Till ſhee diſpayring Hecvba beheld,
stanza.couplet: Staring on Priams wounds with her old eyes,
VVhich bleeding vnder Pirrhvs proud foot lies.

stanza.line: In her the Painter had anatomiz’d
Times ruine, beauties wracke, and grim cares raign,
Her cheeks with chops and wrincles were diſguiz’d,
Of what ſhee was, no ſemblance did remaine:
Her blew bloud chang’d to blacke in euerie vaine,
stanza.couplet: VVanting the ſpring, that thoſe ſhrunke pipes had fed,
Shew’d life impriſon’d in a bodie dead.

stanza.line: On this ſad ſhadow Lvcrece ſpends her eyes,
And ſhapes her ſorrow to the Beldames wœs,
VVho nothing wants to anſwer her but cries,
And bitter words to ban her cruell Fœs.
The Painter was no God to lend her thoſe,
stanza.couplet: And therefore Lvcrece ſwears he did her wrong,
To giue her ſo much griefe, and not a tong.

stanza.line: Poore Inſtrument (quoth ſhee) without a ſound,
Ile tune thy wœs with my lamenting tongue,
And drop ſweet Balme in Priams painted wound,
And raile on Pirrhvs that hath done him wrong;
And with my tears quench Troy that burns ſo long;
stanza.couplet: And with my knife ſcratch out the angrie eyes,
Of all the Greekes that are thine enemies.

stanza.line: Shew me the ſtrumpet that began this ſtur,
That with my nailes her beautie I may teare:
Thy heat of luſt fond Paris did incur
This lode of wrath, that burning Troy doth beare;
Thy eye kindled the ﬁre that burneth here,
stanza.couplet: And here in Troy for treſpaſſe of thine eye,
The Sire, the ſonne, the Dame and daughter die.

stanza.line: VVhy ſhould the priuate pleaſure of ſome one
Become the publicke plague of manie mœ?
Let ſinne alone committed, light alone
Vppon his head that hath tranſgreſſed ſo.
Let guiltleſſe ſoules be freed from guilty wœ,
stanza.couplet: For ones offence why ſhould ſo many fall?
To plague a priuate ſinne in generall.

stanza.line: Lo here weeps Hecvba, here Priam dies,
Here manly Heƈtor faints, here Troylvs ſounds,
Here friend by friend in bloudie channel lies:
And friend to friend giues vnaduiſed wounds,
And one mans luſt theſe manie liues confounds.
stanza.couplet: Had doting Priam checkt his ſons deſire,
Troy had been bright with Fame, & not with ﬁre.

stanza.line: Here feelingly ſhe weeps Troyes painted wœs,
For ſorrow, like a heauie hanging Bell,
Once ſet on ringing, with his own waight gœs,
Then little ſtrength rings out the dolefull knell,
So Lvcrece ſet a worke, ſad tales doth tell
stanza.couplet: To pencel’d penſiuenes, & colour’d ſorrow,
She lends them words, & ſhe their looks doth borrow,

stanza.line: Shee throwes her eyes about the painting round,
And who ſhee ﬁnds forlorne, ſhee doth lament:
At laſt ſhee ſees a wretched image bound,
That piteous lookes to Phrygian ſheapheards lent,
His face though full of cares, yet ſhew’d content,
stanza.couplet: Onward to Troy with the blunt ſwains he gœs,
So mild that patience ſeem’d to ſcorne his wœs.

stanza.line: In him the Painter labour’d with his skill
To hide deceipt, and giue the harmleſſe ſhow
An humble gate, calme looks, eyes wayling ſtill,
A brow vnbent that ſeem’d to welcome wo,
Cheeks neither red, nor pale, but mingled ſo,
stanza.couplet: That bluſhing red, no guiltie inſtance gaue,
Nor aſhie pale, the feare that falſe hearts haue.

stanza.line: But like a conſtant and conﬁrmed Deuill,
He entertain’d a ſhow, ſo ſeeming iuſt,
And therein ſo enſconc’t his ſecret euill,
That Iealouſie it ſelfe could not miſtruſt,
Falſe creeping Craﬅ, and Periurie ſhould thruſt
stanza.couplet: Into ſo bright a daie, ſuch blackfac’d ſtorms,
Or blot with Hell-born ſin ſuch Saint-like forms.

stanza.line: The well-skil’d workman this milde Image drew
For periur’d Sinon, whoſe inchaunting ſtorie
The credulous old Priam aﬅer ſlew.
VVhoſe words like wildﬁre burnt the ſhining glorie
Of rich-built Illion, that the skies were ſorie,
stanza.couplet: And little ſtars ſhot from their ﬁxed places,
VVhē their glas fel, wherin they view’d their faces.

stanza.line: This piƈture ſhee aduiſedly peruſ’d,
And chid the Painter for his wondrous skill:
Saying, ſome ſhape in Sinons was abuſ’d,
So faire a forme lodg’d not a mind ſo ill,
And ſtill on him ſhee gaz’d, and gazing ſtill,
stanza.couplet: Such ſignes of truth in his plaine face ſhee ſpied,
That ſhee concludes, the Piƈture was belied.

stanza.line: It cannot be (quoth ſhe) that ſo much guile,
(She would haue ſaid) can lurke in ſuch a looke:
But Tarqvins ſhape, came in her mind the while,
And from her tongue, can lurk, from cannot, tooke
It cannot be, ſhee in that ſence forſooke,
stanza.couplet: And turn’d it thus, it cannot be I ﬁnd,
But ſuch a face ſhould beare a wicked mind.

stanza.line: For euen as ſubtill Sinon here is painted,
So ſober ſad, ſo wearie, and ſo milde,
(As if with griefe or trauaile he had fainted)
To me came Tarqvin armed to beguild
VVith outward honeſtie, but yet deﬁld
stanza.couplet: VVith inward vice, as Priam him did cheriſh:
So did I Tarqvin, ſo my Troy did periſh.

stanza.line: Looke looke how liſtning Priam wets his eyes,
To ſee thoſe borrowed teares that Sinon ſheeds,
Priam why art thou old, and yet not wiſe?
For euerie teare he fals a Troian bleeds:
His eye drops ﬁre, no water thence proceeds,
stanza.couplet: Thoſe roūd clear pearls of his that moue thy pitty,
Are bals of quenchleſſe ﬁre to burne thy Citty.

stanza.line: Such Deuils ſteale effeƈts from lightleſſe Hell,
For Sinon in his ﬁre doth quake with cold,
And in that cold hot burning ﬁre doth dwell,
Theſe contraries ſuch vnitie do hold,
Only to ﬂatter fooles, and make them bold,
stanza.couplet: So Priams truſt falſe Sinons teares doth ﬂatter,
That he ﬁnds means to burne his Troy with water.

stanza.line: Here all inrag’d ſuch paſſion her aſſailes,
That patience is quite beaten from her breaſt,
Shee tears the ſenceleſſe Sinon with her nailes,
Comparing him to that vnhappie gueſt,
VVhoſe deede hath made herſelfe, herſelfe deteſt,
stanza.couplet: At laſt ſhee ſmilingly with this giues ore,
Foole fool, quoth ſhe, his wounds wil not be ſore.

stanza.line: Thus ebs and ﬂowes the currant of her ſorrow,
And time doth wearie time with her complayning,
Shee looks for night, & then ſhee longs for morrow,
And both ſhee thinks too long with her remayning.
Short time ſeems long, in ſorrowes ſharp ſuſtayning,
stanza.couplet: Though wo be heauie, yet it ſeldome ſleepes,
And they that watch, ſee time, how ſlow it creeps.

stanza.line: VVhich all this time hath ouerſlipt her thought,
That ſhee with painted Images hath ſpent,
Being from the feeling of her own griefe brought,
By deepe ſurmiſe of others detriment,
Looſing her wœs in ſhews of diſcontent:
