stanza.couplet: It eaſeth ſome, though none it euer cured,
To thinke their dolour others haue endured.

stanza.line: But now the mindfull Meſſenger come backe,
Brings home his Lord and other companie,
VVho ﬁnds his Lvcrece clad in mourning black,
And round about her teare-diſtained eye
Blew circles ſtream’d, like Rain-bows in the skie.
stanza.couplet: Theſe Watergalls in her dim Element,
Foretell new ſtormes to thoſe alreadie ſpent.

stanza.line: VVhich when her ſad beholding husband ſaw,
Amazedlie in her ſad face he ſtares:
Her eyes though ſod in tears look’d red and raw,
Her liuelie colour kil’d with deadlie cares,
He hath no power to aske her how ſhee fares,
stanza.couplet: Both ſtood like old acquaintance in a trance,
Met far from home, wondring ech others chance.

stanza.line: At laſt he takes her by the bloudleſſe hand,
And thus begins: what vncouth ill euent
Hath thee befalne, that thou doſt trembling ſtand?
Sweet loue what ſpite hath thy faire colour ſpent?
VVhy art thou thus attir’d in diſcontent?
stanza.couplet: Vnmaske deare deare, this moodie heauineſſe,
And tell thy griefe, that we may giue redreſſ.

stanza.line: Three times with ſighes ſhee giues her ſorrow ﬁre,
Ere once ſhee can diſcharge one word of wœ:
At length addreſt to anſwer his deſire,
Shee modeſtlie prepares, to let them know
Her Honor is tane-priſoner by the Fœ,
stanza.couplet: VVhile Colatine and his conſorted Lords,
VVith ſad attention long to heare her words.

stanza.line: And now this pale Swan in her watrie neſt,
Begins the ſad Dirge of her certaine ending,
Few words (quoth ſhee) ſhall ﬁt the treſpaſſe beſt,
VVhere no excuſe can giue the fault amending.
In me mœ wœs then words are now depending,
stanza.couplet: And my laments would be drawn out too long,
To tell them all with one poore tired tong.

stanza.line: Then be this all the taske it hath to ſay,
Deare husband in the intereſt of thy bed
A ſtranger came, and on that pillow lay,
VVhere thou waſt wont to reſt thy wearie head,
And what wrong elſe may be imagined,
stanza.couplet: By foule inforcement might be done to me,
From that (alas) thy Lvcrece is not free.

stanza.line: For in the dreadfull dead of darke midnight,
VVith ſhining Fauchion in my chamber came
A creeping creature with a ﬂaming light,
And ſoﬅly cried, awake, thou Romaine Dame,
And entertaine my loue, elſe laſting ſhame
stanza.couplet: On thee and thine this night I will inﬂiƈt,
If thou my loues deſire do contradiƈt.

stanza.line: For ſome hard fauour’d Groome of thine, quoth he,
Vnleſſe thou yoke thy liking to my will
Ile murther ſtraight, and then ile ſlaughter thee,
And ſweare I found you where you did fulﬁll
The lothſome aƈt of Luſt, and ſo did kill
stanza.couplet: The lechors in their deed, this Aƈt will be
My Fame, and thy perpetuall infamy.

stanza.line: VVith this I did begin to ſtart and cry,
And then againſt my heart he ſet his ſword,
Swearing, vnleſſe I tooke all patiently,
I ſhould not liue to ſpeake another word.
So ſhould my ſhame ſtill reſt vpon record,
stanza.couplet: And neuer be forgot in mightie Roome
Th’adulterat death of Lvcrece, and her Groome.

stanza.line: Mine enemy was ſtrong, my poore ſelfe weake,
(And farre the weaker with ſo ſtrong a feare)
My bloudie Iudge forbod my tongue to ſpeake,
No rightfull plea might plead for iuſtice there.
His ſcarlet Luſt came euidence to ſweare
stanza.couplet: That my poore beautie had purloin’d his eyes,
And when the Iudge is rob’d, the priſoner dies.

stanza.line: O teach me how to make mine owne excuſe,
Or (at the leaſt) this refuge let me ﬁnde,
Though my groſſe bloud be ſtaind with this abuſe,
Immaculate, and ſpotleſſe is my mind,
That was not forc’d, that neuer was inclind
stanza.couplet: To acceſſarie yeeldings, but ſtill pure
Doth in her poyſon’d cloſet yet endure.

stanza.line: Lo heare the hopeleſſe Marchant of this loſſe,
VVith head declin’d, and voice dam’d vp with wo,
VVith ſad ſet eyes and wretched armes acroſſe,
From lips new waxen pale, begins to blow
The griefe away, that ſtops his anſwer ſo.
stanza.couplet: But wretched as he is he ſtriues in vaine,
VVhat he breaths out, his breath drinks vp again.

stanza.line: As through an Arch, the violent roaring tide,
Outruns the eye that doth behold his haſt:
Yet in the Edie boundeth in his pride,
Backe to the ſtrait that forſt him on ſo faſt:
In rage ſent out, recald in rage being paſt,
stanza.couplet: Euen ſo his ſighes, his ſorrowes make a ſaw,
To puſh griefe on, and back the ſame grief draw.

stanza.line: VVhich ſpeechleſſe wœ of his poore ſhe attendeth,
And his vntimelie frenzie thus awaketh,
Deare Lord, thy ſorrow to my ſorrow lendeth
Another power, no ﬂood by raining ſlaketh,
My wœ too ſencible thy paſſion maketh
stanza.couplet: More feeling painfull, let it than ſufﬁce
To drowne on wœ, one paire of weeping eyes.

stanza.line: And for my ſake when I might charme thee ſo,
For ſhee that was thy Lvcrece, now attend me,
Be ſodainelie reuenged on my Fœ,
Thine, mine, his own, ſuppoſe thou doſt defend me
From what is paſt, the helpe that thou ſhalt lend me
stanza.couplet: Comes all too late, yet let the Traytor die,
“For ſparing Iuſtice feeds iniquitie.

stanza.line: But ere I name him, you faire Lords, quoth ſhee,
(Speaking to thoſe that came with Colatine)
Shall plight your Honourable faiths to me,
VVith ſwiﬅ purſuit to venge this wrong of mine,
For’tis a meritorious faire deſigne,
stanza.couplet: To chaſe iniuſtice with reuengefull armes,
Knights by their oaths ſhould right poore Ladies harmes.

stanza.line: At this requeſt, with noble diſpoſition,
Each preſent Lord began to promiſe aide,
As bound in Knighthood to her impoſition,
Longing to heare the hatefull Fœ bewraide.
But ſhee that yet her ſad taske hath not ſaid,
stanza.couplet: The proteſtation ſtops, ô ſpeake quoth ſhee,
How may this forced ſtaine be wip’d from me?

stanza.line: VVhat is the qualitie of my offence
Being conſtrayn’d with dreadfull circumſtance?
May my pure mind with the fowle aƈt diſpence
My low declined Honor to aduance?
May anie termes acquit me from this chance?
stanza.couplet: The poyſoned fountaine cleares it ſelfe againe,
And why not I from this compelled ſtaine?

stanza.line: VVith this they all at once began to ſaie,
Her bodies ſtaine, her mind vntainted cleares,
VVhile with a ioyleſſe ſmile, ſhee turnes awaie
The face, that map which deepe impreſſion beares:
Of hard miſfortune, caru’d it in with tears.
stanza.couplet: No no, quoth ſhee, no Dame hereaﬅer liuing,
By my excuſe ſhall claime excuſes giuing.

stanza.line: Here with a ſigh as if her heart would breake,
Shee throwes forth Tarqvins name: he he, ſhe ſaies,
But more then he, her poore tong could not ſpeake,
Till aﬅer manie accents and delaies,
Vntimelie breathings, ſicke and ſhort aſſaies,
stanza.couplet: Shee vtters this, he he faire Lords, tis he
That guides this hand to giue this wound to me.

stanza.line: Euen here ſhe ſheathed in her harmleſſe breaſt
A harmfull knife, that thence her ſoule vnſheathed,
That blow did baile it from the deepe vnreſt
Of that polluted priſon, where it breathed:
Her contrite ſighes vnto the clouds bequeathed
stanza.couplet: Her winged ſprite, & through her woūds doth ﬂie
Liues laſting date, from cancel’d deſtinie.

stanza.line: Stone ſtill, aſtoniſht with this deadlie deed,
Stood Colatine , and all his Lordly crew,
Till Lvcrece Father that beholds her bleed,
Himſelfe, on her ſelfe-ſlaughtred bodie threw,
And from the purple fountaine Brvtvs drew
stanza.couplet: The murdrous knife, and as it leﬅ the place,
Her bloud in poore reuenge, held it in chaſe.

stanza.line: And bubbling from her breſt, it doth deuide
In two ſlow riuers, that the crimſon bloud
Circles her bodie in on euerie ſide,
VVho like a late ſack’t Iland vaſtlie ſtood
Bare and vnpeopled, in this fearfull ﬂood.
stanza.couplet: Some of her bloud ſtill pure and red remain’d,
And ſom look’d black, & that falſe Tarqvin ſtain’d.

stanza.line: About the mourning and congealed face
Of that blacke bloud, a watrie rigoll gœs,
VVhich ſeemes to weep vpon the tainted place,
And euer ſince as pittying Lvcrece wœs,
Corrupted bloud, ſome waterie token ſhowes,
stanza.couplet: And bloud vntainted, ſtill doth red abide,
Bluſhing at that which is ſo putriﬁed.

stanza.line: Daughter, deare daughter, old Lvcretivs cries,
That life was mine which thou haſt here depriued,
If in the childe the fathers image lies,
VVhere ſhall I liue now Lvcrece is vnliued?
Thou waſt not to this end from me deriued.
stanza.couplet: If children prædeceaſe progenitours,
VVe are their offſpring and they none of ours.

stanza.line: Poore broken glaſſe, I oﬅen did behold
In thy ſweet ſemblance, my old age new borne,
But now that faire freſh mirror dim and old
Shewes me a bare-bon’d death by time out-worne,
O from thy cheekes my image thou haſt torne,
stanza.couplet: And ſhiuerd all the beautie of my glaſſe,
That I no more can ſee what once I was.

stanza.line: O time ceaſe thou thy courſe and laſt no longer,
If they ſurceaſe to be that ſhould ſuruiue:
Shall rotten death make conqueſt of the ſtronger,
And leaue the foultring feeble ſoules aliue?
The old Bees die, the young poſſeſſe their hiue,
stanza.couplet: Then liue ſweet Lvcrece, liue againe and ſee
Thy father die, and not thy father thee!

stanza.line: By this ſtarts Colatine as from a dreame,
And bids Lvcrecivs giue his ſorrow place,
And than in key-cold Lvcrece bleeding ſtreame
He fals, and bathes the pale feare in his face,
And counterfaits to die with her a ſpace.
stanza.couplet: Till manly ſhame bids him poſſeſſe his breath,
And liue to be reuenged on her death.

stanza.line: The deepe vexation of his inward ſoule,
Hath ſeru’d a dumbe arreſt vpon his tongue,
VVho mad that ſorrow ſhould his vſe controll,
Or keepe him from heart-eaſing words ſo long,
Begins to talke, but through his lips do throng
stanza.couplet: VVeake words, ſo thick come in his poor harts aid,
That no man could diſtinguiſh what he ſaid.

stanza.line: Yet ſometime Tarqvin was pronounced plaine,
But through his teeth, as if the name he tore,
This windie tempeſt, till it blow vp raine,
Held backe his ſorrowes tide, to make it more.
At laſt it raines, and buſie windes giue ore,
stanza.couplet: Then ſonne and father weep with equall ſtrife,
VVho ſhuld weep moſt for daughter or for wife.

stanza.line: The one doth call her his, the other his,
Yet neither may poſſeſſe the claime they lay.
The father ſaies, ſhee’s mine, ô mine ſhe is,
Replies her husband, do not take away
My ſorrowes intereſt, let no mourner ſay
stanza.couplet: He weepes for her, for ſhee was onely mine,
And onelie muſt be wayl’d by Colatine.

stanza.line: O, quoth Lvcretivs, I did giue that life
VVhich ſhee too earely and too late hath ſpil’d.
VVœ wœ, quoth Colatine , ſhee was my wife,
I owed her, and tis mine that ſhee hath kil’d.
My daughter and my wife with clamors ﬁld
stanza.couplet: The diſperſt aire, who holding Lvcrece life,
Anſwer’d their cries, my daughter and my wife.

stanza.line: Brvtvs who pluck’t the knife from Lvcrece ſide,
Seeing ſuch emulation in their wœ,
Began to cloath his wit in ſtate and pride,
Burying in Lvcrece wound his follies ſhow,
He with the Romains was eſteemed ſo
stanza.couplet: As ſeelie ieering idiots are with Kings,
For ſportiue words, and vttring fooliſh things.

stanza.line: But now he throwes that ſhallow habit by,
VVherein deepe pollicie did him diſguiſe,
And arm’d his long hid wits aduiſedlie,
To checke the teares in Colatinvs eies.
Thou wronged Lord of Rome, quoth he, ariſe,
stanza.couplet: Let my vnſounded ſelfe ſuppoſ’d a foole,
Now ſet thy long experienc’t wit to ſchoole.

stanza.line: VVhy Colatine, is wœ the cure for wœ?
Do wounds helpe wounds, or griefe helpe greeuous deeds?
Is it reuenge to giue thy ſelfe a blow,
For his fowle Aƈt, by whom thy faire wife bleeds?
Such childiſh humor from weake minds proceeds,
stanza.couplet: Thy wretched wife miſtooke the matter ſo,
To ſlaie her ſelfe that ſhould haue ſlaine her Fœ.

stanza.line: Couragious Romaine, do not ſteepe thy hart
In ſuch relenting dew of Lamentations,
But kneele with me and helpe to beare thy part,
To rowſe our Romaine Gods with inuocations,
That they will ſuffer theſe abhominations.
stanza.couplet: (Since Rome her ſelf in thē doth ſtand diſgraced,)
By our ſtrong arms frō forth her fair ſtreets chaced.

stanza.line: Now by the Capitoll that we adore,
And by this chaſt blood ſo vniuſtlie ſtained,
By heauens faire ſun that breeds the fat earths ſtore,
By all our countrey rights in Rome maintained,
And by chaſt Lvcrece ſoule that late complained
stanza.couplet: Her wrongs to vs, and by this bloudie knife,
VVe will reuenge the death of this true wife.

stanza.line: This ſayd, he ſtrooke his hand vpon his breaſt,
And kiſt the fatall knife to end his vow:
And to his proteſtation vrg’d the reſt,
VVho wondring at him, did his words allow.
Then ioyntlie to the ground their knees they bow,
stanza.couplet: And that deepe vow which Brvtvs made before,
He doth againe repeat, and that they ſwore.

stanza.line: VVhen they had ſworne to this aduiſed doome,
They did conclude to beare dead Lvcrece thence,
To ſhew her bleeding bodie thorough Roome,
And ſo to publiſh Tarqvins fowle offence;
VVhich being done, with ſpeedie diligence,
stanza.couplet: The Romaines plauſibly did giue conſent,
To Tarqvins euerlaſting baniſhment.
